After many hundreds of hours in OW1, I quit a short while after OW2 launched, after seeing the insane monetization decisions they made back then. You had to grind like crazy to get a skin, which is fine I guess, it's a skin, just cosmetic, but what bothered me even more was that you actually had to grind to unlock new heroes too, which was a wild decision, since you didn't have all heroes unlocked going into competitive, which ruined the balance completely. 

Anyway, Blizzard surprisingly learned from its mistakes and made a ton of positive changes to everything in the game, after checking it out again this year for the first time since 2022, it really feels like a great and fun game again, and the perk system keeps the competitive mode very fresh. They're a lot more generous with free loot boxes as well.

Hi, someone whose been playing Overwatch since it first came out... Oh boy has it been a ride and nor a good one. My hubby and I originally paid for Overwatch when it first came out. Let's just say I'm the only who plays it now and my hubby use to be diamond (which used to be top 500) when we played. We were pretty f*ing pissed when we heard Overwatch 2 was going out and it was going to be free. Like okay sure, but you're gonna at least give us our money back right... Yeah nope... Never saw that money back... And they got rid of lootboxes...
Blizzard as a company is garbage. We already know this, don't give them your money. It's not worth it. The store is incredibly overpriced, it's ridiculous. Like an actual joke. Good and amazing skins are usually behind a paywall when it comes to any game but Blizzard is just frickin greedy. Sometimes the Battle Pass is worth it and as someone whose tried to play enough so I don't have the buy the battlepass, yeah no... You can buy the battle pass one season and save enough overwatch coins to buy it again but they just want you to pour more money to this game and its not worth. Competitive... To put it lightly is a f*kin sh*t show. It's actually terrible and most of the time your whole team is going to leave and it can be brutal. OW2 community is also garbage. They are incredibly toxic and ppl will literally tell you to off yourself in quickplay. Don't even get me started on how many times they have re-worked heroes. 

I would like to give this game a positive review amongst tons of bad and it's difficult. There aren't many redeeming qualities about this game. Sometimes I do come back to it, usually to play a new hero, then I remember how bad it is.
Some redeeming qualities are that they added lootboxes back but that's not enough to fix a community that is so heartbroken. They abandoned Overwatch lore and to make up for it they keep doing collabs that again are behind a huge paywall. 

The game is free so yeah, why not give it a try but honestly. There are far better games out there to spend your time and money on.

Yep, the release was a catastrophe. Yep, we never got the promised PvE. Yep, the whole switch from 1 to 2 was really tough on the game. But now, after stabilizing and sorting out most of the problems of this game, I can confidently say that this is the best state this game has been in EVER. 
I miss OW1 dearly, it holds so many warm memories in my heart. It's mostly nostalgia tho, nostalgia that consumed most people and they don't realize that what they really want from the game is all the good few memories they experienced, while totally ignoring the bad ones, where we would sit multiple months with OP characters and Metas. 
Now we have a team who is constantly working on this game. Multiple balance patches every couple of weeks, devs who aren't afraid to experiment with wild patches like the Stadium and talents, while still having attention to small details in the visual design of maps and heroes, still showing charm in new voice lines and beatufil skins. Even tho it is kinda bogus that skins cost too much, which would be one of my only critisicms of the game.

Welcome to the democratic world of Overwatch, where the game director is a politician. He starts every blog post and update with "We are listening to the players".

Not gonna hold my breath waiting for the day he actually does some directing instead of mindlessly taking feedback from everyone and trying to be a people pleaser. Guy is literally 2 blog posts away from asking the public for ideas to make up for his lack of plans for this formerly great franchise.

The game is a hollow shell of its former glory since Jeff Kaplan left. Jeff left and took the whole world of Overwatch with him. What's left here is a skin shop disguised as a game, with newer characters literally built from the Sims 4 Create-A-Sim. And flavor text that tries to pass for lore. 

Game Director doesn't care about any of the characters. He only cares about pleasing the people, and sadly, all the people want are skins. Well done us, and well done sir game director for not having a backbone to do right by Overwatch. 

At the state the current world of Overwatch is, I wish I never knew Overwatch so I didn't have to grief for more than a whole ass year. Blizzard used to be a company that built stories and worlds. Now all they build are cosmetics to sell.

We traded the lore and the world of Overwatch for skins. We built a cinematic engine in game just so we can use it for skin trailers, we recycle PvE content into brain dead game modes that nobody plays. 

Balancing and design for the game is also completely stat driven, so if you love seeing balancing done based on the statboard that is the source of all toxicity, do join us. Used to be heroes were able to do more than just dmg and heals, but now most heroes particularly the DPS lineup has been homogenized to feed the statboard. 

All that aside, the core gameplay is good and mostly polished, as it has always been since OW1. So basically nothing changed but everything changed.

If you like skins, come play. We've got plenty at the best prices in the industry. 

"Overwatch was shutdown for a reason" - (Vivian Chase, back when there was lore) Now we know why she said this.

"The Overwatch I joined was about raising the world up" - (Also Vivian Chase, back when she wasn't just a mannequin for skins) Yeah this ain't the Overwatch I joined.

This world used to be somewhere I felt home. Now its just a dead game to me. Sorry I meant skin shop disguised as a game.

The last time I played Overwatch was around 2019-2020, back then I didn't like the concept of hero shooters at all, and I dropped the game at level 23.

But relatively recently, after Marvel Rivals came out, I got a taste for hero shooters and hit Celestial in the second season. With each new season, MR started to appeal to me less and less, so I decided to give Overwatch a try for myself.

I jumped straight into competitive mode and didn't do great in calibration because I hadn't fully figured out the game yet.
It placed me in Bronze 1, but I didn't get discouraged and decided to keep grinding on tank/support.

But after a while, I started noticing a trend: I was getting only 9-10 points per win (in the very best case, maybe 11).
I could understand if I was playing poorly, but even in games where my K/D reached about 5, I still only got 10 points.

And just recently, I decided to do a little marathon session, playing a total of 19 games (12 wins, 6 losses, 1 draw), and my rank didn't budge at all.

I really like Overwatch, but the game itself makes me not want to keep playing it.

This game literally changed my life. Ever since this game came out, all I can do is play Overwatch 2 from the moment I wake up to the moment I fall asleep.

Originally, I purchased this game to play with my friends, but after forcing them to play about five games in a row, they all decided they‚Äôd had enough for the day. My intense desire for Overwatch 2 wasn‚Äôt satisfied, so I moved on to playing against a full room of AI. After my tenth game against five hard AI, I was still not satisfied, but my urge had to wait as I passed out before I could start a new game.

When I woke up, I plugged it in and went straight back to playing Overwatch 2. I played one round with five hard AI, but my urge simply got worse. I figured I wasn‚Äôt getting my fill since it took too long between my turns. I decided to change it to one hard AI, but after about three games I started to get impatient ‚Äî to the point that I was screaming at the top of my lungs, telling the AI to hurry up so I could play.

It was around this time that my mother came into my room, telling me I had woken her up and that she was taking my PC away so she could get some sleep. Rage filled my body and, without even thinking, I punched her directly in the face and started screaming again as her body dropped to the ground.

I took her body, tied it to the bed, and gagged her so that when she woke up she wouldn‚Äôt be able to open her stupid mouth and tell me to stop playing the most amazing game known as Overwatch 2 for the PC.

When I finally got back to my game, my urge was so intense that I decided to start up a local multiplayer game with two players so I would always be playing. After about five games with myself, I started to calm down and realized that life would be okay ‚Äî because I had Overwatch 2, and I never had to stop playing.

In the middle of the sixth game, my mom woke up and I started to hear her muffled screams. I told her she‚Äôd better shut up or I‚Äôd never let her go. After that, she quieted down ‚Äî but little did she know, I would never let her go. I couldn‚Äôt risk letting her, or anyone for that matter, stop me from playing my game.

It‚Äôs now been ten days and I haven‚Äôt stopped playing since that morning. I‚Äôve lost track of how many games I‚Äôve played. I haven‚Äôt left my house, and my friends seem to be worried about me because they‚Äôve called my phone multiple times in the past hour. But I don‚Äôt have time to talk to people who don‚Äôt love Overwatch 2 the way I do.

My mother stopped moving two days ago and is starting to smell ‚Äî but I don‚Äôt care, because I have everything I need: Overwatch 2.

I mostly play turn based jrpgs. I think this is fun because it feels like what would happen if you made a traditional turn based rpg into a real time multiplayer game. It has debuffs, buffs, ultimate attacks, and the same strategy of prioritizing eliminating the buffer/support first, just like how you would in a turn based game. But now since it's real time, you also have to consider positioning and synchronizing with your team. I understand that overwatch gets a lot of hate but I think it still deserves aleast a try with your friends or something.

Reading all the new negative reviews irked the shit out of me, so I might as well answer the common complaints. It says 4.1 hrs on steam, but I got like nearly 1k hrs on battle.net. TOPIC: the game is over hated for outdated reasons (alt title: people like to bandwagon cuz they cant form actual and insightful reviews)

Its previous CEO had a negative impact on the game, especially right before his resignation. So the negative reviews on Steam release were extremely valid as the game were at its all-time low (and the fresh taste of PvE cancellation, even tho none of yall complaining about it will ever actually play it past 30 min). The release of Marvel Rivals was an important competition for Blizzard to improve and be bold. The current dev team are trying to shake off the bad rep the game used to hold.

Now it's very over hated as it is in a much better state with obvious growing numbers (Stadium gamemode catering to more players, reworks and nice visual updates). And to say that the "2" was only meant for 'heavy micro transactions', how tf are they suppose to make money on a free game as a big studio? Sure it was egregiously bad earlier but now there are more discounts and free lootboxes (just ignore the money signs). Sure they said PvE was intended, but things fell flat and reusing story mode concepts into the PvP modes (like in arcade at the moment) to then officially adding perks is a great move. They now have lore info tab so read/watch those too with more coming!

also... YOU HAVE TO PLAY MORE TO PROGRESS MORE. It has more of a meaningful progression, especially for new players (and will continue to be). You'd be surprise with how much you can get rare shop/collabs or previous battlepass items for free just for playing. No need to worry about FOMO.

Hero balancing is understandably frustrating. With 45 heroes, and counting, being added there are bound for someone to counter someone. And with how they are adjusted constantly shifting the meta, at least it's not the same meta every day yk? Every hero is up for potential on the chopping block, or for a promotion, it gets you going. Definitely better now since release.

The matchmaking is all you expect out of an online team-based hero shooter. The ones complaining are the same ones that goes back to rivals with a much worse matchmaking. It isn't perfect. Sometimes you are good in one game, then you become the worse player on your team in the next. It happens. Mostly fueled by egotistical people with their life on the line into winning their games. It's gonna be a wider elo in unrank than on ranked (yes, unrank has a hidden skill rating so it caters roughly to your skill level). Think about who you are playing WITH. Anyone higher or lower than your skill rating is gonna have an effect in your matches, eventually favoring the higher skill = more harder games.

You can make hilarious and creative metaphors to negatively describe each aspect of the game, but it isn't accurate to how it's portrayed, at least in the present times rn. If you care about having a good team with comms, I would suggest discord servers or anything else adjacent (for ANY gamemode, mic or no mic). If you hate the 5v5 format, play 6v6. If you hate your mmr, strive to be better? seek a coach or watch videos and stop being ignorant. 

Not to cocksuck blizzard to say this game is peak and is without flaws. What I am saying tho is that this game is in a much MUCH better state and is OVERHATED 2 lol. Thanks for coming to my ted talk.

Honest long review by me.

I‚Äôve been playing Overwatch since December 2016. Back then, the game actually meant something. Matches took skill, teamwork, and timing. Pulling off a clutch felt earned. Heroes had identity, fights had weight, and every win was yours. Fast forward to 2025 and I barely recognize what I‚Äôm playing. The soul is gone. It‚Äôs a hollow, frustrating shell of what once was one of the best games ever made.

Matchmaking has been trash for YEARS. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs EOMM, SBMM, hidden throttling, or just pure incompetence, but matches feel predetermined. One game you stomp, the next you get thrown into a blender. It never feels like you win because you played well ‚Äî it feels like the system decided the outcome the moment you queued. It‚Äôs exhausting, and it‚Äôs been this way since I first touched the game.

Season 9 was the point where Blizzard completely killed skill expression. Every patch since then is built around flattening the game and making precision irrelevant. Tanks are raid bosses, supports are basically DPS with insane sustain, and DPS is just‚Ä¶ cosmetic. You can land every shot and it still doesn‚Äôt matter because the sustain loop is busted. They call it ‚Äúaccessibility,‚Äù but it‚Äôs really the death of competitive integrity. Years of learning mechanics, tracking, positioning ‚Äî all of that means nothing now.

The devs keep insisting 5v5 is ‚Äúbetter,‚Äù but all it did was destroy the role ecosystem. Tanks feel awful unless they‚Äôre overtuned, supports only shine by turning into mini-tanks, and DPS is irrelevant unless something is accidentally broken. Every balance patch feels like it was designed by developers who‚Äôve never played above Bronze. Instead of fixing meaningful issues, they buff easy heroes, nerf depth, and pretend they‚Äôre saving the game.

Then we have the company behind all this. Blizzard isn‚Äôt Blizzard anymore. The harassment scandals, the studio culture issues, the PR nonsense ‚Äî everything behind the scenes mirrors the state of the game. Hollow, directionless, and full of ego. They talk about ‚Äútrusting the vision,‚Äù but the vision is a dumpster fire.

And the hero identity? Completely gone. They‚Äôve abandoned edgy, skill-heavy heroes like Hanzo, Sombra, and Reaper. Permanent underdogs now. In their place, we get shiny, safe, streamer-friendly characters. And speaking of new characters ‚Äî Vendetta is literally a knock-off Magik from Marvel Rivals. Same look, same vibe, same glowing magic-sword aesthetic. It‚Äôs embarrassing. They really thought their copy could compete with the actual Queen of Limbo? Be serious.

To make it even funnier, Blizzard emailed me saying I ‚Äúqualified for a free Premium Battle Pass due to login issues.‚Äù I never had any. They‚Äôre just handing out passes like apology coupons now. What a joke.

The community is another disaster. Somehow people think Overwatch 2 is at its ‚Äúpeak.‚Äù They cheer for pointless modes like Stadium ‚Äî something nobody asked for ‚Äî while the actual competitive experience is falling apart. It‚Äôs Fortnite with ultimates now. Casual hype drowns out any real feedback, and anyone who points out the game‚Äôs decline gets treated like the problem.

I‚Äôve actually had to force myself to play other games just to feel skill matter again. Need for Speed ‚Äî a racing game ‚Äî gives me more satisfaction because your mistakes are yours. Meanwhile, Overwatch feels rigged or random. Wins and losses feel like matchmaking dice rolls, not performance.

Custom games used to be a place to escape the chaos. Now they‚Äôre ruined too. Fake-friendly lobbies full of creeps, drama, harassment, and weirdos. Blizzard does absolutely nothing. They never have. Moderation is cosmetic ‚Äî just like half the game mechanics now.

Then there‚Äôs the monetization. Every new season is ‚ÄúBUY MORE KIRIKO SKINS,‚Äù ‚ÄúCheck out the new bundle,‚Äù ‚ÄúLook at the new crossover event.‚Äù Everything feels like a commercial. Even hero buffs feel like marketing pushes. The game‚Äôs direction is driven by engagement metrics, not gameplay health. They don‚Äôt balance for fun or fairness ‚Äî they balance for attention spans.

It‚Äôs been a slow, painful decline. I kept hoping the game would recover, that Blizzard would fix matchmaking, revive skill-based play, bring back hero identity. But every patch proves they‚Äôre going the opposite direction. The game gets more chaotic, more casual-focused, more empty.

Overwatch now feels like watching a corpse move. The animations are pretty, the maps are nice, the heroes look cool ‚Äî but the soul is missing. There‚Äôs no tension, no clutch value, no sense that your input matters. Winning rarely feels earned. Losing feels predetermined. Everything that made it special has been replaced by noise, spam, sustain, and monetization.

The casual community celebrates meaningless skins and overhyped updates while ignoring the actual problems. They cheer for fluff while the core rots. It‚Äôs painful to watch a game you loved slowly sink while people clap at the fireworks on the deck.

I‚Äôve held on for too long. I kept telling myself it could get better. But it hasn‚Äôt. Every patch reminds me:
the devs don‚Äôt care about skill, don‚Äôt care about veterans, and don‚Äôt care about the identity this game once had.

Overwatch used to be a masterpiece.
Now it‚Äôs a flashy, hollow shell propped up by marketing, casual hype, and nostalgia.

I wish it wasn‚Äôt this way.

"What we‚Äôre hoping to do with Overwatch 2, is really redefine what a sequel means."
-Jeff Kaplan, 2019

"Overwatch is a team vs team, 6v6 competitive experience. And there's NO WAY we're losing that at all!"
-Jeff Kaplan, 2019

No wonder why Papa Jeff left the company...
His vision of Overwatch 2 has been completely destroyed.

This is not Overwatch 2. This is just Overwatch 1 but intentionally designed to be inexplicably worse. It's ludicrous!

The main reason this game was called Overwatch 2, was the announced and overly advertised PvE missions, with the new hero skill trees, customizable abilities and hero progression, and then after over 3 YEARS of waiting, basically everything PvE related that was announced in this trailer was cancelled*.

On top of that, as an excuse for "working" for all the cancelled stuff, they left in the dust the original game with 3 years of no content at all, because "they were focusing on making the sequel".
So, what they added in the "new" game after these 3 years of no content?
A Battle Pass instead of Loot Boxes
The worst scummy monetization system I've ever seen. Literally everything has to be paid now, including 7+ year old skins that cost 19 euros each.
5v5 instead of 6v6 (which means a hero balance way more broken than before)
Only 3 new heroes (a rate of 1 hero per year)
6 new maps (but they also REMOVED 5 maps)
THAT'S IT! What was the point of the "2" in the title then?
Is literally the same game as 2016, but with even less stuff than before.
Player levels? Gone
Medals? Gone
End game cards? Gone
"Looking for Group" feature? Gone
On-fire system? Gone initially, and re-added later as a "new content" (L.M.F.A.O.)
2CP mode? They had no idea of how to balance it, so they just removed it from the core game entirely.
As this wasn't enough, who bought the original game in 2016 and spent thousands of hours like me, has no choice but stop playing entirely or being stuck playing this hell of a mess with extremely predatory monetization, because they SHUT DOWN the original game despite saying that OW1 and OW2 were going to be playable together**, so there's no way back.
How's that even fair?

Overwatch 2 is what happens when a good game gets kidnapped, held hostage, and forced to work in the cosmetics department. Blizzard didn‚Äôt make a sequel - they made a mobile cash shop wearing an FPS costume. They shut down OW1, replaced it with less content, slapped price tags on everything, and acted like they did us a favor.

Every ‚Äúupdate‚Äù feels like Blizzard sprinting to the bank with a suitcase full of legendary skins. Real gameplay changes? Slow. New modes with actual effort? Rare. PvE campaign they hyped for YEARS? Scrapped‚Äîbecause apparently selling recolors is more ‚Äúcost effective.‚Äù I guess story mode development got outbid by another Kiriko or Mercy Skin.

The shop gets more updates than the GAME. How is that normal? Hero balance can sit broken for months, but the second they can charge $29.99 for an angel with wings or a robot in a hoodie, they‚Äôll push it out like they‚Äôre saving lives. Blizzard didn‚Äôt upgrade Overwatch - they downgraded it and monetized the downgrade.

You know it‚Äôs bad when the main progression system is your credit card.

They removed loot boxes so they could charge you directly. They removed OW1 so they could lock heroes behind paywalls. They removed PvE so they could sell skin packs. They basically removed everything except the one thing players don‚Äôt actually play for: the SHOP.

Overwatch 2 is literally a fashion simulator with occasional shooting breaks.

If you enjoy overpriced outfits more than actual new content, go wild. But if you‚Äôre here for a real sequel, do yourself a favor and don‚Äôt bother. Blizzard‚Äôs main game mode isn‚Äôt Competitive or Quickplay - it‚Äôs Cash Grab: Legendary Edition.

The wildest part about Overwatch 2 is that the core gameplay can still be great ‚Äî those rare moments where teamwork clicks remind you why the series became huge in the first place. But everything wrapped around that core seems determined to smother it. Matchmaking feels like emotional roulette, queue times bounce all over the place, and progression rewards hit with all the excitement of an empty cereal box prize. Then there‚Äôs the ‚Äúsequel‚Äù label ‚Äî which feels more like a marketing stunt than an honest evolution. Blizzard took a game that was already slowing down and somehow morphed it into a slapped-together, cash-draining carousel of recycled content and inexplicable design choices. That big ‚Äú2‚Äù might as well stand for ‚Äú2 more battle passes, 2 fewer reasons to log in, and 2 functioning brain cells left after waiting 30 minutes just to play support.‚Äù The supposedly revolutionary PvE mode ‚Äî hyped for years ‚Äî disappeared faster than your tank in a doomed 1v5. Meanwhile, balance updates swing so violently they might as well be written by a committee of coin flips. One patch turns Cassidy into an unstoppable force; the next makes him about as effective as interior decoration. And matchmaking? Blizzard could swap the algorithm with a blindfold and a dartboard, and I‚Äôm not convinced we‚Äôd notice a difference. Half the matches feel less like competitive play and more like a free trial in stress tolerance.

NOTE: I played significantly on battle net before I started playing on steam. check my achievement to get a feel for just how much time i've put into it.

within the last few months, it's felt like the OW devs have started getting their act together. despite the whole history of betrayal and disappointments, the game in its current state is simply good. proper competition for Marvel Rivals. the "Mostly Negative" reviews are primarily a hold-over from that nearly decade long history of BS after BS.

OW2 no longer carries that "Steve Jobs with the iPhone" spark that it felt like it had back in 2016, and yes you can feel that it's gone. you have a basic battle pass but compared to other games, even compared to marvel rivals, the battle pass in OW is very well implemented and reasonably player-friendly. some mild sadge moments when you discover a great skin was season locked but ultimately their monetization is not bad, especially when you compare it to other games. 

The gameplay is still as good as you probably remember it, there will always be some heroes over-tuned slightly but again, it's not anything new if you've played other kinds of games. 5v5 is a bit simpler, feels like team-based sumo wrestling where you're just smashing your team against theirs. 6v6 is chaotic enough with enough stuff going on that you rely on teamwork way more no matter what role you play, and it is very noticeable. both modes are available and accessible, and in the 80 hours i've played at the time of release, the devs have already put out 2 separate unique event modes with wacky rules and fun experiments. the custom games browser is also a great source of fun and trying how new things.

TL;DR Overwatch 2 is currently a worthy competitor to Marvel Rivals. the monetization is not bad compared to the rest of the industry, just less generous than OW1's "here's everything all the time for free" model. the balance is decent, again not any worse than other games. plenty of fun to be had here, it is definitely worth the $0.00 it takes to start playing.

For everyone reading this review, I've played this game since Overwatch one. The very start of it by the way, and I've also played it competitively. I've earned my right to judge this game. I have over by far 1000 hours on console and over 600 on pc prob more like 800 
 
This game is horrid. Overwatch 1 was great. I am a very major Overwatch 1 fan and will always hope Overwatch one originally comes back. When they took out 6v6 I was very disappointed. 5V5 is terrible. You play tank, you get counter picked half the time you play DPS and if you don't do good enough your team falls apart and you get blamed. Healers if they do not heal enough you get blamed. And then you lose the game. It's a terrible game ever when Nick picks you for the littlest thing. They promised us a campaign, we paid for the campaign for full access and it gets taken away. We don't even get a refund for any of the money that we spent on the past to get the campaign The only thing that we keep are the maps and it was absolutely terrible. 

The battle pass is terrible and I will always stand by that. I've bought it a few times and I personally think it's a waste of money  They took out loot crates to replace it with a battle pass, which I still think is a terrible idea. Everyone was very mad that their loot crates all got opened and they were saving for a massive Loot Crate open for anything like that. 

 

Don't even get me started on the skins. All the OG skins back in the day for Overwatch 1 you can buy them for now for like 30 bucks. For the most recent ash skin for the pool party they just reskin the old one lmao It's absolutely horrendous you can spend $60.00 on 4 skins maybe even 5  

 

For my conclusion of this, I still think this game is just a money grab for Blizzard to milk as much money as they can The game was good, they thought it was going to be coming back when they brought in Overwatch 2, but it was absolutely terrible. The game is dying and will never be the same as it was. Personally I think they can't fix it. They can keep trying to add heroes and make it better and this and that, but it's not going to be better. All the characters that they release are going to always be broken on release date and then terrible afterwards. Same thing happened with Venture The game is dying. That's it. There's nothing you can do. Ohh and no, this is not a rage bait. This is my honest opinion.

I have been playing this game consistently for 5+ years. I have played this game like its a part time job. I'm talking 20+ hours a week. I've taken small breaks at times for my own sanity, but today, I am fed up. I have put so much time and money into this game that doesn't give an F about balancing. When you think of games, you think that they're supposed to be fun. I have been chasing the sparkly feeling I had when I first played Overwatch 1 and its gone forever. 5v5, Tank-Doomfist, never ending support nerfs, unbalanced lobbies, smurfing, boosting, and the unapologetic cash grabs have ruined this game. The launch of Overwatch 2 absolutely obliterated any trust between the developers and the players. And they've really never earned that trust back. Blizzard cares about money, they don't care about you or your experience playing this game. If I can stop even one person from playing this game then leaving this review will be worth it.

The game is in an excellent state, and the reviews don't reflect that. If your opinion of the game is still negative due to the PvE fiasco, be sure to give it one more chance.

You can tailor your own playstyle with perks which have made many characters dramatically more fun to play. Hero bans and map voting were overdue, but incredibly welcome features.

The game now has 3 main modes to play, Stadium, 5v5 role lock and 6v6 openQ, which means there's something for everyone. (I am no longer forced to play against supertanks in 5v5!)

Really my main gripe with the game is that sometimes the balancing can feel a bit...off with seemingly random chances to random heroes. However, you can pretty easily ban the power outliers (if they exist). 

Regarding cosmetics, I don't really care about them personally, but they are still undoubtedly too expensive for what they are. 

Overall, I would say the game is in a really healthy position at the moment (November 2025). The game is well-optimized, competitive, in-depth and good fun.

Overwatch 2 offers everything fans loved about the first game, with a new twist: a shift to 5v5, revamped maps, new heroes, and more aggressive pace. But while the gameplay can be incredibly fun when the matches are balanced, the experience can feel frustrating and uneven when the matchmaking system doesn‚Äôt deliver.

Let‚Äôs start with the positives‚ÄîOverwatch 2 is a blast when everything clicks. The hero-based combat is still exhilarating, with tight controls, engaging team dynamics, and a range of strategies that keep the game feeling fresh. The new additions, like Sojourn and the revamped maps, help reinvigorate the experience. If the match is well-balanced, with teams of equal skill and coordination, it‚Äôs easy to lose yourself in the flow of the game, whether you‚Äôre coordinating team ultimates, landing a clutch headshot as Hanzo, or pushing the payload with your team as you work together to secure the win.

However, that‚Äôs where the problem lies: the matchmaking system. Despite Blizzard‚Äôs efforts to improve the process, Overwatch 2 still struggles with creating balanced teams, especially in higher ranks. The "competitive" mode feels more like a roulette wheel of who gets paired with the better teammates, with games often feeling like one-sided blowouts rather than tightly contested battles. Matchmaking doesn‚Äôt always account for things like team composition, individual skill disparities, or even the all-important synergy between teammates.

In practice, this means you can go from an absolutely thrilling match to an infuriating one where the game feels like it‚Äôs over before it even began. In many cases, you‚Äôll find yourself on a team where players aren‚Äôt working together, or worse, you're stuck with people who are far below your skill level (or way above it) while the enemy team seems to have everything together. The inconsistent matchmaking really pulls you out of the experience, and it‚Äôs frustrating to feel like your victory or defeat is more about the luck of the draw than your actual performance.

Overall, Overwatch 2 shines in its core gameplay when the match is balanced, offering the same chaotic, satisfying, and team-oriented action that fans adore. But until the matchmaking gets tweaked and refined, it can be a bit of a rollercoaster ride, and not always in the fun way. It‚Äôs a game that can be incredibly rewarding, but also one that often leaves you wondering, ‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt we just get one match where both teams feel equally matched?‚Äù

I've been playing since OW1 Release and I've never had this much and this consistent problems with the matchmaker.
Maybe the blame is on me for playing Quickplay but it can't realistically be this difficult to find a balanced match.

For reference I usually am playing with an friend who is roughly the same rank as I in Role Queue.
I also have roughly 680 hours clocked in the different gamemode, with most of them in QP followed by Comp. So it's not like this is coming from an lack of playing or calibration.

If I end up loosing 80% of my matches because the teams are incredibly imbalanced and the other 20% are equally unbalanced, just so happens to be in my favor, something is seriously messed up.

And if I am just "Too Trash" for the MMR I have I would've demoted into an "more appropriate" MMR after 6 Months of trying and playing.

I've been giving the game the chances it deserved, at first I thought they just made some changes to the matchmaker that will be fixed eventually. However multiple seasons have passed and nothing has changed, nothing has improved.

Yes we got cool new features, and perks, and whatnot, but if I can't enjoy a game because it's horrible imabalanced then what even is the point?

If Blizzard just wants us to play Comp then why even have QP in the first place if it's matchmaker is this horribly mismanaged.

It hurts especially since I've been RECOMMENDING the game to my friends over the last year, with the changes that happened it finally felt like a "new" game after all those years of stagnation and lack of care from our overlords Blizzard. But now we're here where I'm adding to the overall negative reviews for this game.


This is just my personal experience, well, mine and that of my friend.
However if you want to give it a shot don't be perusaded by my personal frustration.
Maybe this Matchmaking issue is just affecting me and my friend, maybe it's just a local issue and you'll have a great time.

But from my experience I can no longer, and won't anymore stand up to the bullshit that is this matchmaking.

I first played Overwatch 1 back in 2019 on Battlenet so all of my hours in this game are on that platform (1500+). The launch of Overwatch 2 was rough, and the canceled PvE has left Overwatch with a tarnished reputation. Despite this, the developers have remained extremely passionate for this game and have worked so hard to rebuild and improve it. Overwatch 2 is in the best state it has ever been in. Perks, Stadium, 6v6 back in the game, hero bans, map voting, competitive drives, a reasonable hero release schedule, mythic skins and weapons, lootboxes (you can't even buy them, they are not predatory in any way), a revamp of the progression system, better and more consistent balance, lore back in the game, and Overwatch classic (which in some cases proves OW2 is in its best state because some of the OW1 patches are miserable to play with insta kill dps doomfist, poor balance, and tons of stuns and CC abilities) have all made Overwatch 2 an incredible game. Do not hesitate to give it a try. The game is in a great state and has many fun heroes, modes, rewards, and so much more to offer.

Why You Should Not Play Overwatch 2: A Critical Examination
The world of video games is constantly evolving, with new titles promising fresh experiences and improved gameplay. However, not every sequel lives up to its potential, and in some cases, it even detracts from the legacy of its predecessor. Overwatch 2 is, unfortunately, a prime example of this phenomenon. Once hailed as a promising evolution of Blizzard‚Äôs beloved team-based shooter, Overwatch 2 has instead become a cautionary tale in the gaming industry‚Äîa game riddled with design missteps, corporate greed, and community disappointment. This essay explores the many reasons why Overwatch 2 is a horrible game and why gamers should think twice before investing their time, money, and hope in it.

1. The Illusion of Innovation
When Blizzard announced Overwatch 2, fans expected a meaningful sequel with significant improvements and new content. Instead, what they received was an incremental update masquerading as a new game. The much-touted shift from 6v6 to 5v5 gameplay did little to fundamentally alter the core experience. Maps, heroes, and game modes were slightly tweaked, but the changes felt superficial at best. Many players noted that Overwatch 2 played almost identically to the original, with only a handful of new heroes and maps that could have easily been introduced as updates to the first game.

Perhaps the most egregious example of this lack of innovation is the handling of the promised PvE (Player vs. Environment) mode. This feature was heavily marketed as the cornerstone of Overwatch 2, setting it apart from its predecessor and justifying its existence as a sequel. However, Blizzard eventually scrapped the ambitious PvE campaign, leaving players with a glorified patch rather than a true sequel. This broken promise eroded trust and demonstrated a fundamental disregard for the community‚Äôs expectations.

2. Monetization and Corporate Greed
If there is one aspect where Overwatch 2 stands out, it is in its aggressive monetization strategies. The original Overwatch adopted a ‚Äúbuy once, play forever‚Äù model, with cosmetic items available through loot boxes that could be earned through gameplay. While loot boxes are controversial, they at least allowed dedicated players to unlock content without spending additional money.

Overwatch 2, on the other hand, is free-to-play‚Äîbut at a significant cost. The introduction of battle passes, expensive cosmetics, and paywalls for new heroes has transformed the game into a cash grab. Players now have to pay real money or grind for dozens of hours to access new content, and the prices for skins and bundles are exorbitant. This shift in philosophy prioritizes profits over player enjoyment, creating an environment where those who pay are often rewarded more than those who play.

Moreover, the decision to lock new heroes behind the battle pass undermines the competitive integrity of the game. In a title where team composition and hero selection are crucial, forcing players to unlock heroes through progression or payment creates an uneven playing field. This pay-to-win perception has alienated both new and returning players, further damaging the game‚Äôs reputation.

3. Disregard for the Community
A successful multiplayer game thrives on its community, but Blizzard‚Äôs handling of Overwatch 2 demonstrates a striking lack of respect for its player base. Communication has been inconsistent, with frequent delays and vague updates about the game‚Äôs direction. The scrapping of the PvE mode, as previously mentioned, was not only a broken promise but also a blatant disregard for the excitement and anticipation of long-time fans.

Additionally, the forced migration from Overwatch to Overwatch 2, which included the shutdown of the original game‚Äôs servers, left many players feeling betrayed. Those who preferred the original‚Äôs mechanics, balance, or business model were given no choice but to adapt or quit. This move eliminated player agency and erased years of gaming history, all for the sake of pushing a lackluster sequel.

Toxicity and cheating have also become more prevalent in Overwatch 2. Despite promises of better moderation and anti-cheat systems, many players report that these issues are worse than ever. The lack of meaningful community tools, such as robust reporting and matchmaking improvements, has only exacerbated these problems.

4. Gameplay and Balance Issues
On a fundamental level, Overwatch 2 suffers from numerous gameplay and balance issues. The shift to 5v5 has not been universally well-received. Many players feel that the loss of a second tank has made matches more chaotic, less strategic, and more punishing for solo players. The meta is often dominated by a handful of overpowered heroes, while others languish in obscurity due to poor balancing.

Frequent balance patches and hero reworks have not resolved these problems; in some cases, they have made things worse by introducing new bugs or unintended consequences. The game now feels less like a carefully crafted competitive experience and more like an experimental testbed, where players are subjected to constant changes and disruptions. This instability is frustrating for both casual and competitive players, who crave consistency and fairness.

5. Technical and Quality-of-Life Failures
Beyond its design flaws, Overwatch 2 is plagued by technical issues and a lack of quality-of-life improvements. Server problems, long queue times, and frequent disconnections are common complaints. Despite being marketed as a next-generation upgrade, the game still suffers from outdated graphics, clunky user interfaces, and limited accessibility options.

Basic features that are standard in other competitive games‚Äîsuch as robust stat tracking, replay systems, and customizable controls‚Äîare either missing or poorly implemented. These oversights further contribute to the sense that Overwatch 2 is a rushed and incomplete product.

6. The Decline of Blizzard‚Äôs Reputation
Blizzard was once a name synonymous with quality and innovation. The company‚Äôs decline has been well-documented, from controversies over workplace culture to questionable business decisions. Overwatch 2 represents the culmination of this downward spiral‚Äîa game designed more by committee and corporate mandate than by passion and creativity.

By supporting Overwatch 2, players are not only endorsing a mediocre game but also enabling the practices that have led to Blizzard‚Äôs fall from grace. There are countless other games, both old and new, that deserve your time and money more than this disappointing sequel.

Conclusion: Choose Better
In summary, Overwatch 2 is a deeply flawed game that fails to justify its existence as a sequel. It offers little innovation, prioritizes monetization over enjoyment, disrespects its community, and suffers from numerous gameplay and technical issues. The forced migration from Overwatch to its inferior successor is a stark reminder of how far Blizzard has strayed from its roots.

If you value your time, your money, and your love for gaming, do not play Overwatch 2. There are far better alternatives that respect their players, foster positive communities, and deliver genuinely innovative experiences. Let Overwatch 2 serve as a warning: demand more from the games you play, and never settle for less.

The bad
To start off, I started Overwatch at the start of 2017, I've seen it both rise and fall to say the least. For the longest while in 2020-2023 the game was so bad I would rather play any other game in existence. I would even go to play Placid Plastic Duck Simulator competitively. No updates, no new content, and a failed promises of a PvE campaign that was canceled a full year before OW2. Most heroes were reworked so differently in that span of time that it felt like a heap of trash trying to fight another heap of trash every game. I really don't need to shed light on the old developer team. Everybody knows the damage they did.

The good
I am glad to say that progress is being made. The reworks have balanced the roster better than before. The graphics engine has been overhauled and optimized decently. (I played with a GTX 980 TI and just upgraded a week before this review) The balancing actually helped make the game fun again. But, some heroes are specialized for specific things, specifically Roadhog being a maximum survivability tank now. 

Just though I should add this, Matchmaking has been updated recently. Skill based matches are in both ranked and quickplay now. It feels way better not having impossible to win matches around every corner. I mean, you lose the steamroll games where you crush the other team, but its a fair trade.

Now that Marvel Rivals has came out Overwatch has some actual competition and pressure towards community feedback. But I highly doubt that it can come back from the reputation damage from the old OW developer team and the ongoing greed from Blizzard. Right now it is actually really fun, most of the toxic players jumped ship to Rivals. Overwatch is in a good shape overall for me to recommend to either returning players or new players.

Unjustified ban, my account just got suddenly banned for violating in game code of conduct. I rarely chat in game or never use in game voice chat(I have social anxiety btw, only use discord with my lil brother), never use cheats, I played the game the way in meant to be played(I usually play support most of the time) and never throw. They don't even give you a warning or suspension, just straight up banning you. Now I feel like the money I spent in the game, especially this season, got wasted and my little brother is upset by this too, since we play this game together most of the time together. He told me that it was unfair that I got ban, and that it should be him because he chats more often in game and sometimes argue with someone. He also stop playing the game after that. And, this is the first time I got banned in a game too.

I appealed once and explain everything, after a couple of hours they just sent me another email saying a game master resolved the ticket or appeal. It didn't really mention if my account got unban or they rejected it. Well, it turns out they rejected it, because the ban is still there. I tried to appeal again and ask for proof or evidence day after day but never got a response until now.

Edited: I just received their response today and I got accused of using third party software and they didn't clarify what software(I only use discord with my little brother when playing.)
Yeah, I'm not getting my account back. They won't let me appeal anymore. This sucks, I quit Overwatch now. My money and time just got wasted for an unjustified ban.

Last Update: Surprisingly, I got my account back this morning which I'm really glad at and in relief. I received an email that says that my account closure has been an error. They compensate with the premium battle pass next season. I still hope that they will improve their reporting system so this kind of incident will be avoided.

On Steam Deck:

Select Overwatch
Press Options (‚ãØ) ‚Üí Manage ‚Üí Uninstall

Alright, let's actually provide a constructive review. Why are people "review bombing" Overwatch 2?

We paid for Overwatch, we supported it throughout its lifespan, it was popular and liked by its community, and turning a happy profit each year.

When Blizzard announced Overwatch 2, the big new feature they announced, the entire premise that made it "worth the sequel treatment" was the PvE campaign mode. Hero talent trees, customizable abilities, an expansive co-op campaign that would add to the story and lore. We were told it was going to be so much work that they wouldn't be putting out updates for Overwatch any more, they were re-allocating the staff to work on this new project.

With no updates, and no content, Overwatch started to get stale... people grew tired and bored, spending less time in the game, or moving on. Many of us stuck with the product, playing a little each week just to keep fresh... waiting for the new campaign mode. For a lot of us, playing became a chore, something we were doing out of habit, so we'd be ready for the new campaign...

But the new campaign wasn't the premise that established OW2, it was the pretext. It was a lie. Blizzard abandoned the PvE campaign a full YEAR before OW2 launched - but continued to push it in marketing as the big new feature. It's even in the announcement trailer for OW2, and on the roadmaps. They knew they'd canned it 12 months earlier, but they knew that's what people wanted, so kept putting it front and centre to get people's money, to get people to buy into the project. They took our trust and monetized it.

-----

What does OW2 ACTUALLY offer then? What did they work on for those two years that was so important that they couldn't make content for OW1, the product people paid for and were supporting?

1) They overhauled the graphical engine:

Before, Overwatch would play on a relatively low spec computer, and it'd be smooth. Now, it stutters and stammers in the menus. They've added this weird shiny plastic finish to everything in the world, heroes and environment alike - so where before, heros would "pop" against the background and be easy to follow, now everything has the same texture to it, and it all merges together into visual noise - especially at longer ranges. They've compensated for how bad this looks by adding lots of additional flashy effects and explosions, that makes it much harder to see anything amidst the chaos. A PvP game at this pace relies heavily on quick disambiguation of what you're looking at, so you can react and compete, and the new engine makes this impossible without turning all the effects back off... meaning that the two years of development is for a feature best disabled.

The new engine also has a weird slippery "feel" to it. Reviewers who'd played Overwatch for 50 hours came into Overwatch 2 and reported "look! it's the same Overwatch you love, but it's F2P now! Just ignore the monetization and you can play this great game for free!" Established long term players with thousands of hours were on reddit complaining that their hitboxes were all over the place and shots that would previously "feel" like a dead certain hit were just completely whiffing, and they didn't understand why. All the timings are messed up.

2) They reworked most of the heroes:

TLDR: they screwed up the game balance. Previously, one of the biggest appeals of Overwatch was that you could find a hero that suited your play style, and main them, getting good at whatever suited you best. Some people like sniping, or hitscan run and gun, some people aren't good at reactionary aim and instead liked to focus on positioning, tactics and strategy. You could make a big positive different to your team by playing lucio or mercy, and paying attention to your surroundings, and positioning yourself in the right place at the right time to make the difference.

With Overwatch 2, the damage and healing behaviour has been reworked heavily. Now, the one tank on the team is insanely chunky, and it's near impossible to kill them quickly - with healer support, they can just stand in the line of fire and laugh. Everyone else dies almost immediately, regardless of who their aggressor is.

Team-fighting now is very one-note, you have one tank who's immortal if they have support, and you have four hitscan DPS characters following them - there's not a lot of difference between supports and DPS characters. The teams try to pick off the other team's DPS/Support characters, and when they pick a few off, they can finish the tank and take the objective. Repeat. There's no room for variation in play style at all, you either play a DPS and try to kill the other team DPS, or you play a tank, and try to position correctly - maybe picking off an enemy hero that gets too close to you.

I understand a lot of this came from feedback at the professional levels, where support players were complaining that they wanted to have more direct impact in teamfights, they wanted the game to feel more like other FPS games - but for a large portion of Overwatch's playerbase specifically, the appeal of the game was that you could do something else and still matter.

3. They got INCREDIBLY greedy with the monetization...

It's a longstanding argument that lootboxes are terrible in modern gaming... but Overwatch was one of the few examples of Lootboxes done right. Most of the long-term players of the game actually liked the system, that just rewarded you for playing the game and let you unlock whatever content you wanted relatively quickly. I started playing OW1 with the first anniversary, cleared the weekly boxes from arcade every week, and at the launch of OW2, I owned every single item in the game. Those who didn't have the time to invest in doing everything could still quickly unlock specific items they wanted (and let's be honest, when you have your favourite skin, how much do you care about unlocking other skins?) - and those who didn't want to spend hours unlocking stuff could spend a little cash to get it - if they wanted to.

The new system puts almost everything behind a paywall. The minute number of cosmetics on the "free" track are often insultingly lazy, simple recolours or minor alterations, while they put serious effort into skins that you can only buy for $20. The content you can unlock by grinding often feels like it only exists to drag you into interfaces that advertise the paid content for you. Even content from the first game, that was originally free, is now paid only.

Battlepass systems suck. "Pay us for the opportunity to unlock stuff if you play a lot. If you don't you have to pay us more, or lose the stuff you already paid for." - Limited time deals, rotating shop offers, FOMO FOMO FOMO... it reeks of manipulation and insincerity.

4. Occasional DLC packs of PvE adventures.

These are Blizzard's "new" approach to PvE. Occasional mission packs where you can get a little bit of story and a PvE mission. You can pay (in my UK currency) ¬£13 for the DLC pack, or ¬£35 (the cost of a good indie game" for the "ultimate bundle".

So here's the thing - this content is the same amount of content, and the same pace of release as the old mission scenarios - it's just now, instead of them being a free event to get people excited about playing and encourage their friends to join up - now they're paid DLC.

Nobody likes paying a regular subscription for a product that they previously owned completely. It doesn't make anyone like Adobe Photoshop or Microsoft Office, and it doesn't make anyone like Blizzard.

-----

So this is why people are "review bombing" your game. You took something we paid for, supported and enjoyed for years, lied to us about your plans, and turned it into trash. Now you're telling us to pay for features and content we previously enjoyed in the game we paid for. It's greedy, it's cynical, it's manipulative, and you've lost our trust.

Also you should fire Bobby Kotick.

I understand a lot of the frustration that people have for this game. Teammates can be very frustrating at times and the launch of the game was rough for a lot of people along with bad monetization and broken promises. I agree with all of those, yet I'd be lying if I said I did not enjoy this game. The story/characters alone have so much to offer and I love hero shooters where I can fit myself into a role and then a character that suits me. Overwatch can be rough at times but I believe if we continue to voice our frustrations and offer genuine solutions to the issues we have, we can make this game reminiscent to the game that got game of the year all those years ago.

When playing Overwatch 2 a match can go one of two ways.

1. You absolutely cook the enemy team and win flawlessly (you never get POTG tho)
2. You get absolutely DEMOLISHED by the enemy team, primarily their Bastion who somehow has their ultimate every 20 seconds. 

You think to yourself "Oh lets play this character i like this character" NOPE. if you dont play the character you are unironically mediocre (your best character) at, YOU WILL BE PUNISHED. Trying to capture point? "Nerf this!" sigh. Get a full team kill solo in overtime and carry the game? The POTG goes to either Bastion or some stupid character who made one good play at the start of the game that didnt really do that much for the team. But mainly Bastion. You think "Oh, maybe ill play Bastion this time, thatll work"  Of course not! Yes, you get 15k damage and somehow the POTG goes to Moira, but you get spam hated on in chat for playing that annoying character. You still lose, by the way.

In conclusion, I love Lucio. Play Lucio. I will forever respect anyone that plays Lucio. Marry me Lucio.

After years with Overwatch 2, I‚Äôm stepping away because the competitive ranking system feels fundamentally unfair. In too many matches, players who contribute little lose or gain the same rating as teammates who carry the game. That parity rewards inactivity and punishes effort, making team play feel thankless. It‚Äôs exhausting to watch matches derailed by inactive teammates and still see identical rank adjustments across the board. Other games‚Äîlike Marvel Rivals‚Äîhandle performance-based ranking more effectively. Until Overwatch 2 meaningfully accounts for individual impact in its competitive mode, I can‚Äôt recommend it.

Focuses too much on bloat over quality. 
Compared to the original early in its life this game lacks impact and punch in the combat. Now it feels way too watered down with way too much flashing and flooding the screen. Default controls are more often than not an inconsistent annoyance between heroes. 
For a game with such a supposedly high concurrent player count the wait times often take longer than a single or even multiple matches. Not to mention the coin-flip poor server connections once you do connect.
Nice groundwork that has become worn thin with too many "make it fresh" attempts.

I loaded into Overwatch 2: Stadium expecting a casual match.
The announcer yelled, the lights flared, and suddenly I was sweating like it was the finals of the Overwatch World Cup ‚Äî except everyone on my team was role-playing as background NPCs.

My tank charged into the enemy team before the gates even opened.
Our Widowmaker was doing parkour on the stadium lights.
The Lucio spent the entire match DJ‚Äôing instead of healing.

Meanwhile, I ‚Äî a humble Cassidy main ‚Äî was trying to hit shots while dodging D.Va bombs, Sigma rocks, and crippling performance anxiety from the digital crowd screaming in 7.1 surround sound.

At one point, the enemy Rein typed ‚ÄúEZ‚Äù in chat, so naturally our Genji wrote a 3-paragraph essay about team diff and ‚Äúsupport responsibility.‚Äù
I haven‚Äôt seen that kind of passion since the actual World Cup.

I lost the match 0‚Äì3, but I did land one clean Deadeye in overtime and felt like Tom Brady with a revolver.

9/10 ‚Äî The only game where you can play in a stadium and still get booed by your own teammates.
Would absolutely sign up for another season of mental damage.

I'll throw in a recipe for Varenyky.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour ‚Äì 500 g
Water ‚Äì 200 ml
Egg ‚Äì 1
Salt ‚Äì 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes ‚Äì 1 kg
Onions ‚Äì 2
Lard or butter ‚Äì 50 g
Salt ‚Äì to taste
Ground black pepper ‚Äì to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Saut√© the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the saut√©ed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or saut√©ed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

It's a mixed bag with this one.
I've been playing since 2017 OW1 
In it's current state of this review OW2 has improved, but still many things that should be acknowledged. 

1. It's built like Fortnite to put it simply. Paying for skins that are simple Epics all the way up to Mystic. It has it's equivalent to a battle pass which is it's seasons pass which doesn't make up for the overwhelming amount of skins they continue to drop that you have to spend money to pay for. This is only seen as negative imo because OW1 had only loot boxes which was an element to playing that earned you loot boxes and the excitement to open one and hope to get a Legendary skin or anything else which was always cool. Sure they brought them back in OW2 after the community complained, but then how they set up the loot box system there is nothing that you get from it now because they aren't adding new skins consistently that you can get without purchase from the shop, or even at least a chance to get mystic gems or credits to purchase skins from the shop. 

2. A positive is the core of the game playing heroes in matches that in itself is fun it's always been that way. The heroes are unique there is action, skill, game sense, teamwork and team strategy involved it hits ALOT of solid game notes and game winning plays can be made consistently it's all up to you and how you play in that match with your team. 

3. A negative again is an aspect that surrounds the game and that's how they decide what heroes get new skins. It's purely player based and so money based for them. They use the data from game and release skins based on what heroes are played the most/favored. For example Mercy, everyone knows she is the most played and most favored over all heroes, she ALWAYS has a new skin. There are heroes that have a solid fanbase but may not be as large, so say Mercy has 50 new skins that other hero will have 1 within that time frame. That's all to say they're clearly out for the money, and so really don't cater to all players in every aspect.

There is more to be said, but overall I do recommend the game for the gameplay itself that's why the community still exists and alot of people still play despite the negative reviews, but you should know the surrounding features of the gameplay you'll definitely develop your own opinion on it and it's what sparks the negativity.

They just can't keep a good thing going.

If you had asked me at the release of stadium, I would have said Overwatch is saved (and in fact, I did)! They did what I and many others thought were impossible, they made the game fun again! Stadium was some of the most fun I've had in Overwatch, or any hero shooter, ever. All they had to do was add new heroes, and maybe a few more items. Thats all I needed, at least.

But then they added drafting. Each team takes turns selecting heroes, and if someone on the opposing team picks your character, you don't get to play them! Why? I don't know! Thankfully, they reverted that decision within a week of release, since it was so unanimously hated. I gotta give them props for that. The draft remained, but no character lock. Yipee! Back to the miraculously fun game mode.

But the they went and did it again. They went and introduced a quick play version of Stadium for a shorter, more casual experience. 5 rounds instead of 7. Nothing wrong with that, not everyone wants to commit to a full comp game, and thats alright. 

But then they made the Competitve mode the same length (5 rounds) as the quickplay mode!?! For what? Queue times? They sacrificed the entire appeal of the longer, more strategic format so they can shave off a few minutes of queue time? This SUCKS. There is no slow buildup anymore, you just show up and roll or get rolled, Almost every game I played ended on round 3, I never once had a team come back from a losing position. Theres no anticipation, no thought. You just go in, play mostly regular Overwatch round 1, get 80% of your build for round 2, and end things on round 3.

Maybe they'll revert these changes like they did the Hero Lockout, but every season I'll be dreading the next update. What will those geniuses try next? How will they disrupt my fun this time? I don't know, but I DO know that they're eventually going to pull some bullshit that no one asked for. 

I cannot possibly recommend this game to ANYONE, because even if you think its fun now, they are inevitably going to ruin it somehow.

Don't think they actually want people to play. 

-Full screen banner ads at start(spaced out by a few milliseconds of menu visiblity to make think you've reached the end before they slam another in your face)
-Instant game shutdown for updates(no menu, cant change skins, if you were looking at something in the store... no you weren't, bye) 
-Random game session drops on highspeed networks(you'll get dropped, banned for two hours and just have to sit there and shrug, no way to dispute it)

All-n-all , the issues listed here are not quite enough to uninstall on a whim. The game play is still fun enough to keep you engaged. However if anyone of these issues were to become worse i feel it would push the ticket for the games remaining player-base.

What are my feelings about Overwatch?
It's complicated. 

I started playing way back whenever Mercy had originally only had guardian angel, and her ultimate which was rez. For a while, I played it religiously. As in got to masters in healer (with Ana and Mercy), Diamond with damage (Mei and Sombra) and finally Diamond in tank (With Zarya and Reinhardt). I thought I was pretty good at the game, and everything else. 

Hearing about the shutdown, I was pretty bummed. I knew the game meant a lot of new things, which I was reluctant to like because of change, but I figured nothing like that bad could happen.

With that thought, I figured taking a break would be fine. (For only like five-six months).

And that's whenever I played Overwatch 2. I played, and despised it. It's very money hungry with the fade of battle-passes and in order for you to properly get any prizes. I used to own everything that was Mercy related, but as soon as I looked at the heroes, I noticed I was missing quite a lot. (That's just a personal thing, it just peeved me lol)

The reworking of characters was also quite a shock. The Sombra changed through me through a whole loop, and I found it difficult to work with her mechanics and aim for so long until even now I kinda just see what happens. Mercy's jump was another big thing, where before you had to time it JUST right to go super high in the air? It was added to the game anyway. (People who didn't main Mercy wasn't super aware of it and it was GAME CHANGER).

Then the introduction to DOZENS of new characters. I personally felt so overwhelmed trying to figure out how any of them worked especially whenever it came without very *clear* ways to do it. We got several new healers, tanks and of course damage players. Which, was totally okay. (It was just a lot to catch up on, learn about, how to counter, etc).

Then comp. As I mentioned before, I was obsessed with playing it. I had practiced and everything else beforehand and was nailing Quick Play over and over with wins. I even went my main, thinking that everything would be fine. But, as I have seen comments that focus so much on the match-making, I could NOT agree more. I felt like I was with teammates that genuinely had no idea what they were doing. I don't mean making small mistakes, I mean having the lone tank charge into the back, die, then blame the healers. 

And I kept thinking maybe, I am the problem. But it kept happening, over and over and over. I put in my all, changed when needed, but literally nothing was working. Then with the new system they have for competitive, it decided to say what they think my rank would be before I actually finished. 

SILVER.
They tried to compare me to SILVER players. (Which I need to preface, nothing wrong with silver, but going from masters to silver is terrifying).

I hadn't touched competitive since then. So, what are my thoughts on this game?

It used to be quite the charmer of a game, with many characters with unique personalities, abilities and even so much lore to unpack. It was my favorite game for YEARS. Tied with The Walking Dead Video game series! (By TellTale + Skybound) But, even as I nearly have one hundred and fifty hours on just this account, I have over thousand on Overwatch originally. I think if they kept loot-boxes as a main prize counter, fixed and updated the matchmaking, and even just kept the same joy from Overwatch, the user reviews wouldn't be 'Mostly Negative'. 

But, that's my relationship with it.

P.S.
I do agree with the comments mentioning that Blizzard is just trying to use this game and nostalgia in order to get more and more money from you. It's utterly annoying that they want you to spend upward of fifty dollars for some prism skin, and the upgraded battle-pass. But, that's my spiel.

I'm an OG player of overwatch since 2016. I've reached T500 multiple times in ow1 and ow2. I've downloaded the steam version to finally put a review.

TLDR : the current game is in a very poor state. It's only there to sell you mercy and kiriko skins. Gameplay and matchmaking is 6 feet under the ground. Balance is poor. Gameplay feels meh compared to what it used to be. There is no competitive integrity and the game is entirely unfun, frustrating and utterly toxic. Keep yourself safe and out of this game.

I've waited very long to finally make a review. But this game is passed redemption since more than a year now, even after Marvel Rival got out, the game didn't improve much.

I've played the game since 2016. It used to be fun in ow1, the game might have been stale for a long time but it was still enjoyable to play even without much content. The ladder didn't feel too bad. Then ow2 came with big monetization. Which is technically not a bad thing as it helps putting out more content.

However, only the first few season of ow2 were nice to play and enjoyable then 5v5 became completely atrocious to play since S9. We're currently in S19 and none of the terrible changes from S9 were reverted (bigger hitboxes, bigger bullets, 250 base HP for squishes, etc). The team keeps believing that the current 5v5 version of the game is the "main game mode" while it feels terrible to play.

The overwatch team that made the game in 2016 is long gone and there is not anything from what made the game great left into the game today. The team barely ever listen to the community's feedback even when most of the reviews of their game are negative.

The balance is quite poor, the devs do not play their own game and the little part who does only play in very low elo where players don't know how to play the game. They take win/loss ratio statistics and buff/nerf heroes only based on that. Which makes them missing the point every time they make an update to the game.

The competitive integrity of the game has been atrocious since forever and it's gotten even worse since ow2. For the record in T500 ranking there is more than 50% smurf account which means players in T500 is not even close to 500 players. There were seasons where one player had 9 accounts in the top 10 which he got by manipulating the matchmaking by queue sniping, wintrading and abusing duo queuing with lower ranked smurf accounts with his friend. And the overwatch team didn't care the slightest about that.

You'll say "ok but it's only for the T500 ranking", nope. Most players in this game above gold (and even lower) have multiple smurf accounts that they use to "have more fun" by stomping lower elo players. This is how bad it is, if they want to have some fun, ppl just go and smurf which makes everything being even worse.

People also use smurf account to avoid sanctions after being uber toxic and silenced or banned on other accounts. Which means there is no point in reporting people as they all have 5 or 6 accounts which they rotate between bans. You get mass reported anyways for simply communicating whether it's toxic or not so most people are simply silent people scared of talking. I've been silenced just by defending myself while being insulted by someone else. You can simply say "hello" and get mass reported and sanctioned. Nobody checks the reports, it's all automated.

You have people going around being racist, homophobic, sexist, harassing people in game chat and even adding you on friendlist when they're muted just to keep harassing people and they can get away with it for days before being finally silenced for a couple of weeks. Once again, the team doesn't do anything against this type of behaviour.

The game is simply here to sell you battlepass skins centered of 3 female heroes that are popular. The mercy community is funding 90% of this game just by bying skins. The overwatch team is not interested into anything else. They just want to sell skins as much as possible before their game actually dies so they can make the investors happy for a few more quarters.

Each patch is worse than the other. Adds worse feature to the game that look good on paper but feels terrible to play. Take stadium mode as an example. The mode was fun and refreshing in its first season, then each single patch they made on the game mode made it worse. It suffers of long queueing time that has never been adressed effectively despite the changes to the matchmaking. They losened the matchmaking to the point legend players can be matched with rookie players who have neve played the game mode. Now there isn't something that deserved to be called "matchmaking" in this mode. And even with this, higher ranked players from all stars and above will have between 10 and 30mins queue. They added a quick play stadium mode which resulted in even longer queue times. Then they swapped from bo7 to a bo5 which was a disaster. Not to mention the draft mode they added that almost killed the game mode and makes it much much worse than it was.

All the features they added like "map choice", "ban system" made the game actually worse than it was. Those feature works well in a professional environment but on the ladder where gold players don't understand the game they are using those features completely wrong. Often sabotaging themselves and/or their own teammates by banning the heroes their own team wants to play. 

The team laughed at the community by saying "you guys want 6v6 back, ok we're gonna make a test mode". The 6v6 "test" mode was never an actual test as blizzard never put any balance work into it and then said "see, 5v5 is better, it's gonna be the main game mode". I'm not advocating for 5v5 or 6v6, it's just hypocrite to say to the community 5v5 is prefered while they didn't test it at all. Give us a full season with only 6v6 ranked as a role queue main game mode and collect data from it instead of throwing a game mode that is poorly made to say "see, it's bad".

None of the feedback from the community is actually listened despite the many content creators, streamers and seasoned players who actually play the game for multiple hours a day. The devs have simply no idea what to do with the game to make it better and throws random stuff at the wall to see what sticks.

All in all, this game is not worth investing any time in it. If you play a few games and you're lucky you'll have fun. Maybe with some friends if you fool around in quick play. This game has lost its soul and keeps getting worse. Stay away from it and your life will be better. That's the sad reality.
