‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è A Dynamic, Polished, and Addictive Evolution of the Hero Shooter Genre

Overwatch 2 has truly cemented itself as one of the most thrilling and well-crafted team-based shooters available today. Building on the legacy of its predecessor, Blizzard has managed to refine, modernize, and re-energize the entire experience while keeping the heart of what made the original game so special. Every match feels alive with energy, personality, and a constant drive to improve ‚Äî both as a player and as a team.

üéÆ Gameplay: Fast, Fluid, and Strategic

Overwatch 2‚Äôs 5v5 format is a brilliant evolution. Removing one tank streamlines the action, making battles more readable while still retaining depth and strategy. Each hero feels distinct, and no two matches ever play out the same way. Whether you‚Äôre darting across the map as Tracer, raining justice from above with Pharah, or commanding the frontline as Reinhardt, every role feels purposeful and exciting.

The pacing is spot-on: matches move quickly, encouraging aggressive play without losing the tactical nuance that made the series famous. The balance between mechanical skill and team coordination creates a gameplay loop that‚Äôs both competitive and immensely satisfying.

üß† Heroes and Roles: Personality Meets Precision

The hero design in Overwatch 2 is second to none. Every character oozes charm, from their visual design to their voice lines and abilities. The reworks ‚Äî especially for classic heroes like Orisa and Doomfist ‚Äî breathe new life into old favorites, while newcomers like Sojourn, Kiriko, and Lifeweaver feel fresh and thoughtfully crafted. Each hero has a clear identity, and learning how they interact with others is a rewarding process that keeps the game endlessly replayable.

üåç Maps and Visuals: Stunningly Crafted Worlds

Blizzard‚Äôs attention to detail shines through every map. From the sunlit streets of Esperan√ßa to the neon lights of Midtown, the artistry is breathtaking. These environments aren‚Äôt just pretty ‚Äî they‚Äôre expertly designed for balance and flow, with countless routes and flanking options that reward smart positioning and teamwork.

The game‚Äôs visuals are crisp, colorful, and optimized beautifully, ensuring smooth performance even during chaotic team fights. Combined with the soundtrack and voice acting, the world of Overwatch feels alive and inviting ‚Äî a rare feat for an online shooter.

‚öîÔ∏è Competitive and Casual Modes: Something for Everyone

Overwatch 2 caters to all types of players. Competitive play is intense and rewarding, offering a clear sense of progression and improvement. Meanwhile, Quick Play, Arcade, and custom game modes keep things relaxed and experimental. Even the PvE story missions, though limited so far, show great promise and deliver cinematic-quality experiences that expand the lore in exciting ways.

üí¨ Community and Teamplay: Where Magic Happens

Few games capture the magic of collaboration like Overwatch 2. When a coordinated push comes together ‚Äî the tank holds firm, supports keep everyone alive, and DPS land their shots ‚Äî it‚Äôs a feeling of pure exhilaration. The communication tools are intuitive, the ping system is helpful, and when you‚Äôre in sync with your team, the game becomes something truly special.

üîÑ Constant Updates and Support

Blizzard has shown real dedication to keeping Overwatch 2 fresh. Frequent hero balance changes, seasonal events, and the introduction of new heroes and maps ensure there‚Äôs always something to look forward to. The evolving battle pass and cosmetic system provide meaningful progression without forcing players into paywalls, and the devs‚Äô engagement with the community has noticeably improved since launch.

üåü Final Verdict

Overwatch 2 is more than just a sequel ‚Äî it‚Äôs a love letter to teamwork, creativity, and competition. It takes the best parts of the original and evolves them into a sleek, modern experience that‚Äôs both accessible to newcomers and endlessly deep for veterans.

Whether you‚Äôre playing casually with friends or grinding through competitive ranks, every match offers a new story, a new challenge, and a new reason to hit ‚ÄúPlay Again.‚Äù

Overwatch 2 is simply one of the most enjoyable, polished, and personality-driven shooters of this generation.

Final Score: 9.5/10 ‚Äì An exhilarating, ever-evolving hero shooter that‚Äôs bursting with heart and fun.

Unless you are an ultra-casual player who doesn't want to spend money on the game (for the 5 million cosmetics they put out for Kiriko, Juno, & Mercy), do not bother playing this game.

Man, I love Overwatch!

Anyways, do you know about groups of people called cargo cults? They are mostly robust, isolated groups of people living on an island. At some point, usually during wartime, large planes from other countries will land on these islands, usually to set up camp and have supplies, cargo, be brought to them. The indigenous people see these large flying structures and huge boxes filled with foreign objects, things that move or do things that they have never seen. These people will start to believe that the ones that have set camp are some sort of prophet or divine being that has descended upon them. They believe that these people bring great things and that the objects they hold are things that can only be made with divine powers. Once those who set camp leave, however, the indigenous people are left with the hope of their return. They begin to build large structures, similar to things like planes or control towers. They built these out of stick and logs, hoping for the foreigners to one day return and bring more divine objects.

Anyways I hope one day blizzard will bring back cool stuff.

I have 1.5k+ hours on battle.net.

Overwatch 1 was good, but Overwatch 2 is so much better in its current state. Playing the classic mode makes you realize how shit it used to be. Most of the recent negative reviews here are just people viewing Overwatch 1 through the lens of nostalgia, reminiscing about 6v6 and whatnot. The game also has more competition from other titles now, which is healthy. So many QoL updates have made the game feel so much better, along with the numerous balance changes over the years. Also, the game being F2P with constant updates is a blessing compared to what we had before. I play it all the time, both solo and with my friends. It's really fun, casually and competitively.

It's a fairly balanced hero shooter. You could main any hero and make it to a high rank. The skill ceiling on some characters is insane, you will always be learning playing this game. It has a rich roster to which new heroes get added every couple seasons. However, hero design has been rather uninspiring for the recently added ones.

One downside is that tons of people are toxic in this game. Unfortunately, you will be shit on by everyone and their grandma no matter what you do, especially if you're new to the game. Though, if you avoid falling for the rage-bait it's not too bad. There is a report-system but it is notoriously unreliable.

I see lots of people complaining about the monetization of the game. It is free to play. All heroes are unlocked for everyone. The person with all the skins will not have an inherent advantage over you. In addition to that, Overwatch also has one of the most generous loot box systems I've come across in video games, providing you with the same purchasable skins for free, just from playing. You couldn't even buy loot boxes if you wanted to. 

I never really cared about the PvE they were working on, but it sucks they failed to deliver on it for OW2. It has mostly been recycled into perks, the Stadium gamemode, and Story Missions. I do wish they expanded on the lore of the game a bit more. I've heard big things are coming our way regarding the Overwatch story, so let's hope for the best!

The game is in a really good state right now but it is still important to be critical of the less than ideal parts of it. 

All in all it's a fun game that will challenge you both physically and mentally.

I played during Overwatch 1 and to make a long review short, this game fucking sucks. It has completely ruined the game play that made it fun in Overwatch 1, I played Doomfist and Sombra in Overwatch 1, there abilities and gameplay was fun and unique even if Sombra was not that good of a character. But not in Overwatch 2, Doomfist is a tank which is the most unfun role to play unless you have a group of friends, and they keep changing and nerfing Sombra so that she can't even be recognized as the same character anymore. The game has not fixed match making and constantly makes people who solo queue like me have to fight against groups of players who team together, who actually communicate and coordinate with each other, while if your in solo queue their is a 90% chance people on your team will not be in team voice chat and will not hear any of the call outs that you make. 

I play tank and it is by far the single worst role to play in the game, it is literally one of the most stressful fucking jobs if you wanna do well, you have to keep in mind nearly every fucking element of the game to be effective. Not only that but even if you personally do well, if the dps or support on your team do not do a good job then your somehow the problem and they will call you shit and flame you.
 
As a tank you have to:
- Keep in mind the positions of your dps to know if you should apply pressure or not.
- Know what kinds of hero's your support are so that you know how much you can get away with.
- Keep in mind the enemies abilities and what they have, note every single skill usage you can see and hear so that you know what you have to fight against.
- Keep in mind the environment so that you can use it or avoid it. Which includes things like abilities that can change the layout of the map like Mei and her walls, or if your playing characters that can use the environment to your advantage.
- Constantly watch the flanks so that you don't get flanked.
- Have to deal with constant CC and insane damage from nearly every direction and angle.
- Somehow be at the same time cautious and careful so you don't push in to much and die and be aggressive enough to pull all the attention towards you. 

As the tank you are the single most important role on your team as if you die a team fight will most likely end then and there. So that also means that if you are losing or your team is doing badly there is a high chance people will blame you no matter what. If your dps flank and die 6+ times in a row and the enemy have a easy path to flank and kill your back line, they will blame you for them dying and ask why you did not help them. If your support(s) dies from any number of attacks or abilities and you as a tank have to face off against the enemy team with 1-2 supports down and then die because you have not heals, they will blame you and question why you always die even though they are the ones that are meant to heal and support you. Even if your support are literally doing more damage then healing and have 5+ deaths, they will still blame you stating that you should have protected them. People expect tanks to do nearly everything, they expect you to deal damage, to be a meat shield, to know when to push or pull the fight, to have perfect awareness about every ability that was used and the location of not only your team but the enemy team, and also be the anchor which the team rallies around. Teammates will expect you to perfectly understand their plans even if they do not communicate it at all, if you do not understand their vague message about their ult being ready or they are low, then its your fault.

They cranked the damage to 11 in Overwatch 2, they made it so that if you are not receiving near constant healing you will die insanely quickly. I remember when Reinhardt's shield could withstand a lot a enemy attacks and keep up for multiple seconds to help create an opening for your team to do damage, now its destroyed in under 8 seconds of fire and more used sporadically to block hits that actually matter and not just regular fire. When playing tank there is no room for mistakes, if your playing dps or support, if you die but your tank can hold out then you can come back and try again, but if you as a tank die then you lost the team fight and your team mates will flame your out for it. This entire thing would be half manageable if Blizzard did not balance with a fucking sledge hammer, they change major elements of the game and you have to constantly keep that in mind. They change major parts of a character to entirely change their play styles sometimes, they change your effectiveness widely, sometimes making some tanks absolutely the best and the meta, and regulating others to the trash bin, sometimes Zarya is the undisputed best tank, or Winston, or its what ever new tank is added, and you have to know it because their is one one tank on a team now so while the dps and support can play non-meta characters and have a little effect, if you don't play the meta or the counter to your opponent then you have a major disadvantage. Finally as the only tank on your team you are going to get counter picked, where the enemy team changes hero's to specifically counter you. So if you like playing characters like Hammond, Doomfist or really whatever, the enemy will switch to counter you, then if you don't switch then your 'throwing' and your team will complain.

This is the reason that the queue times for tanks is usually under 1 min and other roles are 2-6 minutes long, no one wants to play this awful fucking role. Don't play Overwatch, but if you have to or really really want to, then play any other role then tank.

I'm a new player brought into this entire genre from Marvel Rivals' launch, to its slow settling into the smaller player numbers where it now sits. A few back-to-back negative changes and the matchmaking on Rivals brought me to try out OW2 over the summer. I remember playing a bit of the original OW but I was not a big fan of how it played, so I know I'm in the minority here, but OW2 truly is a fantastic game to play. If you're coming from Rivals the first thing you'll notice is the polish, better matchmaking, more creative and intuitive character design, smooth gameplay, and much more intelligently designed maps. It's also more competitive/sweaty, mechanically challenging, the menu design sucks and looks ancient imo, and the shop/skins and optional paid content tends to be of lower quality and more expensive. 

However, as I'm sure you can see the negative reviews, we shouldn't pretend that Blizzard has not made significant strides in making overwhelmingly positive changes to the game. We shouldn't forget the cancelled PVE content, or the erasure of the original game that so many people loved. But for better or worse, and as what many would consider a direct result of Marvel Rivals, Blizzard is making a real effort here now. So as someone who really jumped into OW2 during the summer of 2025 AFTER the good changes had been made, I truly think in their current states, OW2 is the better game and a fantastic investment of your time and patience to master the learning curve, especially in ranked. 

I don't think Marvel Rivals is going anywhere (contrary to the current sentiment), however I do think OW2 is the king of the genre for a reason, and it shows in the current iteration of the game. So I'll be playing, and buying skins/battlepasses like a pay pig, to send my message to Blizzard that THESE ARE THE CHANGES WE WANT. 

Who knows, if they keep this up, we may even get PVE or an Arcane tier show for the character's lore, which is so fantastic and underutlizied. So Thank Rivals, appreciate both games, and play the one that vibes with you best. For now, I feel like my time is more well appreciated and spend in OW2, at least until Rivals fixes that horrendously manipulative matchmaking system and certain characters that should not see ranked play. GGS

This game fucking sucks. Playing it is a genuine slog with almost zero redeeming qualities. Easily the best part is that a lot of the characters are interestingly designed and fun to play. However, there are equally as many characters who are terribly designed and make you want to uninstall by being on the other team. There's no soul like the game used to have. Where once they cared about progressing the story they no longer do. All they do is release a new cinematic explaining the backstory of a random character that's unimportant to anything and doesn't progress any of the plot that people expected from this game. The monetization sucks. Skins cost at or upwards of $20 and collab bundles cost more than the games they're collaborating with. There's blatant cosmetic favoritism where some characters have basically no skins at all while others get them constantly. Characters like ball, baptiste, venture, and lucio have to wait YEARS to get a new legendary while characters like juno and kiriko get cosmetics constantly pumped into their veins like they're recovering from a DUI in the hospital and are hooked up to an IV. Wuyang already has as many skins as hazard despite only being out for a month and a half, while hazard has been out for almost a year. They put more effort into collab cinematics than they do anything that is relevant to the story of their game. The gameplay is trash, most of the characters people play have one OP ass ability that's super frustrating to deal with that you always have to play around but takes almost zero effort for them to pull off using effectively. Most of the character kits that I like are on tank, which sucks because tank is an absolutely miserable role to play. It's the most banned class, and you can't commit to playing a character you like because the game becomes a match of counterswapping chicken. Some tanks hard counter eachother so you have to constantly swap to counterpick them when they counterpick you, and it just makes the gameplay unfun and boring. There are some characters who can counter your entire character with one ability (Ana alone counters almost all of them). It especially sucks when the most played tanks have are the best at countering so you kind of just have to swap if you see them depending on who you're trying to play. You have to play a hero with some kind of barrier basically every game because your team can't stay alive for shit if you try to play a dive tank and distract half the enemy team. You also always get blamed for losing despite having to swap characters the most out of any other role. The perk system doesn't even improve the gameplay because basically every character just chooses the objectively better perk and ignores the other one. It just adds snowballing rather than fixing anything. The only "good" changes they've made were in response to Rivals coming out and taking their entire playerbase, so they got desperate and had to start trying to make actually good changes. Hero bans is ok but there are characters who just get permabanned so there is almost no variety from game to game. Map voting is fine, but there's always a chance you get 3 shit maps and have to pick one, or one person votes for flashpoint when nobody else does and it goes there. The POTG system is also horrendous and values things way out of proportion from how they should actually be, which is especially bad because they've trademarked the system so better games aren't allowed to use one like it. In short, gameplay bad, monetization bad, updates bad, company decisions with the game bad, game bad. Don't play

Overwatch 2 is a very fast pace hero shooter that is a lot more competitive than it might seem at first glance.
For a short recommendation, i dont recommend this game to anyone because of bad balancing and matchmaking.

[b]Matchmaking[/b]
There either is no matchmaking in Overwatch 2, or its rigged to be extremely bad for new players. Every match I played as a new player was against Grandmaster and Champion ranks. These are the two highest ranks in the game from a total of 8 ranks. Im falling off the maps still learning where the pathways are, while the enemy team has the skill and experience to kill me in 0.5 - 1 second. To make matters worse, my team has a single player of similar skill level as ''balance''.
Ive played with a friend who is experienced and the matchmaking is like this, and when I play solo the matchmaking is the same. There is no place to learn the game with a matchmaking that is this bad.

[b]Community[/b]
People dont communicate, and if they do its through the tiny text chat. A lot of people are extremely toxic and thats honestly no wonder with the matchmaking being as it is. You will get an experience similar to young people playing Call of Duty on console. Swearing using sicknesses and criminal accusations like ''pedo'' are extremely common. There is always someone to blame for something.
Ive had a single grandmaster player apologize to me for the bad matchmaking, and thats the best interaction ive had in 6 hours.

[b]Balancing[/b]
Aside from the horrible matchmaking, the characters are also poorly balanced. There are autoaim and beam abilities that outdamage anything skill based, and one hit kill abilities. AoE abilities that draw someone in, so there is no counter. 

[b] Privacy[/b]
Blizzard requires a lot of personal information in order to make an account, and its done in steps so you feel the need to complete the next step. This scummy way of asking for more and more information is a pretty big red flag ''you already provided all this, so might as well give more''.
Blizzard asks for your [u]Full name & Address, Date of Birth[/u] even though the game is rated 12+. [u]Email Address[/u] with verification, and [u]Phone number[/u] that also requires to be verified to check if its your real number.
The only thing they dont ask for is your personal ID number and the funny numbers on the back of your credit card.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I wish I had time back when Overwatch 1 was a thing so I could have experienced that, since the gameplay and gamemodes seem like they could actually be really fun. Unfortunately Blizzard ''Entertainment'' killed off the servers to Overwatch 1, only 10 months after Overwatch 2 came out... so that chance is gone.
I dont recommend playing this game solo nor with friends.

Not sure what the hate is, i bought OW1 for the intent of multiplayer gameplay not singleplayer.
When OW2 dropped they promised a singleplayer experience at some point but who cares lol, its a multiplayer game and always has been.

I don‚Äôt really get why people complain so much about skin prices - they‚Äôre just skins, lol. Most of the negative reviews are either from people mad that the game went free, salty 2016 veterans, or just random nonsense about porn (seriously?)))
The game doesn‚Äôt make you pay for modes, characters, or Prime status - and that‚Äôs already plus.
If you wanna play - just play.
The mode and map selection system before each match is actually really nice ( IMO ). Skins look good, and the collaborations are fun. I caught the One Punch Man sale-collab - not a fan myself, but it looked cool. Definitely better handled than the Apex anf Final Fantasy one (though yeah, they did let you swing a sword there, heh‚Ä¶)
Workshop - pretty cool addition. It‚Äôs the same feature many players asked for in other shooters (like Apex), but never got :D
Also, the game itself works as a really good aim trainer. It has every kind of shooting - clicking, tracking, vertical and horizontal aiming, even switching targets. That‚Äôs a huge plus (at least for me) In something like CS, you mostly deal with horizontal clicking and switching, but here you‚Äôve got everything
Shooting feels good, the pace is fast (thanks for not being Valorant - it‚Äôs probably closer to Quake) The heroes are diverse, and finally it‚Äôs not just six ‚Äúmeta‚Äù picks. You can actually find someone that suits your style.

On the downside - weird FPS drops from 180 to 80‚Äì110 in some matches, plus short freezes. And sometimes, the first map after launching game runs at around 60‚Äì80 FPS for the first minute(+-) before stabilizing back to 180. Some people say the game takes a long time to close, but I don‚Äôt really care - okay, minus. (And something about ALT + F4, but I haven't tried it yet )

I think I‚Äôll update the review after I hit around 100 hours, but for now, the overall impression is positive.
P.S. And really - why should I care what you think about it?      c:

Nach all den Jahren mit Overwatch hat mich der Stadium-Modus endlich wieder richtig gepackt. Nach √ºber 5.000 bis 6.000 Stunden Spielzeit auf meinem Battle.net-Account f√ºhlte es sich erfrischend an, wieder etwas Neues zu erleben, das gleichzeitig an die taktische Tiefe des alten Overwatch erinnerte.

Gerade im Competitive-Modus war Stadium anfangs wirklich spannend: Es gab strategische Elemente, Raum f√ºr Comebacks, und selbst Spiele, die zu Beginn nicht gut liefen, konnten durch kluges Teamplay noch gedreht werden. Das sorgte f√ºr Nervenkitzel und echten Spielfluss ‚Äì genau das, was Overwatch fr√ºher ausgezeichnet hat.

Leider hat sich das mit der √Ñnderung auf nur noch f√ºnf Runden komplett ge√§ndert. Der Modus f√ºhlt sich jetzt unausgewogen, hektisch und frustrierend an. Man wird, sobald eine Runde nicht ideal l√§uft, schnell ‚Äûoutgefarmt‚Äú und hat kaum Chancen, das Blatt zu wenden. Dadurch ist viel von der taktischen Tiefe und Spannung verloren gegangen, die den Modus urspr√ºnglich so besonders gemacht haben.

Unterm Strich hat diese √Ñnderung f√ºr mich pers√∂nlich das Spiel deutlich verschlechtert ‚Äì ja, sogar ‚Äûkaputt gemacht‚Äú. Aus einem spannenden, teamorientierten Erlebnis ist ein kurzatmiger, wenig belohnender Modus geworden, der kaum noch an das erinnert, was mich an Overwatch immer fasziniert hat.

Overall I did enjoy this game... A long time ago. (Only because of my friends, honestly I have always despised this game.)
I played it on Xbox and moved to PC, played on battle.net for a few years until it moved to steam eventually.

This game has been shrouded in controversy, from name changes (#Notmycowboy) to just straight up abandonment from the developers.
It's funny that since the change of leader ship and shipping out those "Unsavory" characters, they're taught to say no means no... Then the new developers just say yes to everything, like this is life's equivalent of a pet hamster you've had for 4+ years. Don't know if it'll really move anymore but it's still there, twitching ever so slightly from time to time.

The only thing that really brought me back was Stadium, it was refreshing builds were interesting there was a massive change, a perfect shift into what would continue the legacy... (Although 3rd-Person is by far the most moronic thing to put in this game and players who use that stuff should be relegated to their own dumb servers.)

Nope they run head first into nobody asked for this territory, I find the recent changes of Stadium were one of the biggest let downs in this games history, disappointing, daft attempt at claiming all the Adderall using genji mains favor, folks who can't even tie their own shoes.
Followed by my most hated character of all time, Sojourn.
But the biggest let down, was doing such a massive change, literally adding characters, giving Gadgets, and Comp changes without a proper process for any of them, a full non stop horrid collaboration of raining parades.

I understand that I am bad at the game, honestly Plat is where I will lie for the rest of my life, I strive to be average and this is no different. But it's a shame that Overwatch claimed to strive for excellence, and yet failed their own ideals, it never had to be Overwatch 1.

It just had to be Overwatch.

Since I am on the topic, Blizzard is a large dev but with how the IPs are treated they're more like a small indie company who fails to recognize exactly what they're doing, which is simply shameful.

I will be getting the Junkrat mythic skin though then probably leave the game until they reverse changes like every AAA dev does nowadays, truly tragic where we have fallen as a circle of people who wanted the same thing.

look i'm not gonna pretend i don't like this game. and it certainly isn't because of nostalgia, i liked apex legends more but dropped it when i realised ea was just going to keep getting worse.
but overwatch? i'll be honest, it's dug itself out of a pretty big hole. perks and stadium especially are really fun additions, and i honestly prefer the modern hero design compared to how it used to be. also, lootboxes being back as just free extra stuff is great, feels weird to say i like lootboxes but here we are. plus, ranked drives are a pretty fun thing to do at the end of a season, pretty good rewards for playing comp in general honestly.
but theres issues, and i'll keep it simple. as good as the skins themselves are, i feel like i get my moneys-worth from dead by daylight and marvel rivals more when i think i've got some spare cash to spend on a game i like. overwatch is pricey, and theres no realistic way to get new shop skins for free unlike other games. also, the prices for the ultimate battlepass or whatever its called, and especially prisms are a joke. there is no way in hell i am spending ¬£35 on a weapon skin, regardless of how many flashy effects are on it. also, minor gripe, plz plz spread the skins around, and maybe make them less, idk, "horny-bait".
but in simple terms, if you're good with not spending too much on a game, give overwatch a shot (again). it's clear that the games in good hands again, and more importantly, the team has and will make meaningful changes. theres a lot of effort.

Game matches you with vastly different skill ranks - which makes you either a burden or having burdens.
When you get a good matchup, it can be a great experience for both teams, but its often a stomp on either side due to uneven matchups.

Bad matchups with toxic teammates makes this game even worse as they will quarrel, or complain.
They don't understand when the server assigns us low ranking teammates, we just have to make do with it and no point quarreling with them.
Same goes for teams when we are the low ranked, they will ask you to kill more - as though demanding that or scolding teammates can increase the DPS/healing/skills of the teammates.
However dumb they are, if the servers does a better matchmaking job I believe this issue can be lessen.

Oh yes, and the numerous DCs that is a server problem - which punishes your groups of friends as the server kicks them out and suspends them for an hour so you can't play competitive together for an hour, hence ending the  day of play with friends or switch to quickplay.
Its horrendous, and so many people gets kicked by the server randomly, and we don't know why, and we get punished for it.

Pretty amount of flaws I would say.

On the bright side, when they work well, the game is great.
A good matchmade round will have an exciting fight for both teams, and when the servers are great, no one gets kicked, and usually the toxic people wont sound out when the game is balanced (though some still have complaints)

The game runs well besides the server kicking, and the graphics are nice, collabs are good and there are many interesting mini games to play

I‚Äôve put around 2,000 hours into Overwatch, starting on console with a group of friends before switching to PC in 2019. It‚Äôs always been one of those games I could sink into to relax and take my mind off real-world problems. The cute, colorful art style and the endlessly interesting hero interactions make it a genuine treat for the mind, and it‚Äôs hard to find another shooter with this much personality.

I took a break for a few years, but the new perk system pulled me right back in; since then, Blizzard has been delivering steady wins. Honestly, Marvel Rivals might have been the best thing to ever happen to the game because it pushed them to improve again. The new Stadium mode feels like a half-baked response to Valve‚Äôs Deadlock, though it‚Äôs still a cool idea in concept.

Overall, Overwatch 2 is at its best when it knows what it wants to be. It just needs to avoid falling into the old trap of trying to please everyone.

A Love-Hate Relationship From Hell
Bro, this game is like dating your ex who keeps gaslighting you but somehow makes you laugh mid-argument. Overwatch be out here looking all shiny and fun, and then BAM ‚Äî some sweaty Genji wipes your whole team while your healer‚Äôs busy breakdancing in spawn.

The game slaps when it‚Äôs good. You land a clean ult combo, everyone‚Äôs hyped, your ego‚Äôs through the roof ‚Äî pure dopamine. But then matchmaking hits you like a bus full of bronze players who think ‚Äúobjective‚Äù is a suggestion.

And don‚Äôt even start on queue times. I could legit learn a new language waiting to play DPS. Meanwhile, tank mains out here built like war veterans ‚Äî traumatized but respected.

Blizzard, fix your dang servers and stop dropping ‚Äúbalance patches‚Äù that make one hero god-tier and another literal cardboard.

Still‚Ä¶ I keep coming back. Because deep down, I‚Äôm addicted to chaos. Overwatch ain‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs a lifestyle of pain, laughter, and emotional damage.

Final rating: 9/10 when it‚Äôs working, 3/10 when it‚Äôs not ‚Äî overall, a solid 6/10 rollercoaster I can‚Äôt quit.

GOOD GAME

[h1] The Great: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Voice acting is quite good, each character has a very distinct personality and aura you can feel (which can be actually kinda helpful in avoiding ults lol).
[*]The sound design is very clear and crisp, which believe it or not, is quite important in a game that is very heavy on teamwork (at least kind of, I'll get to what I mean in a sec).
[/list]

[h1] The Good: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Character designs can range in quality, but for the ones that are good, especially female... there's a reason for why Overwatch has so many "tags" if you catch my drift.
[/list]

[h1] The Bad: [/h1]
[h3] Ah hell... [/h3]
[list]
[*]Matchmaking sucks. If you want to have some fair fun, party up with friends.
[*]Some of the things that I actually kinda liked(???) in Overwatch 1 that are just... gone here. 
[*]The characters are not very well designed. This isn't entirely the fault of Overwatch, there is certainly the fact that this is straight up a fundamental flaw for a wide majority of "hero shooter" games at large.
[b]1.[/b] This mostly derives from the lack of customization. Now, there is [i]some[/i] degree of customization via the selection of perks, but these perks are really not enough to justify the existence for a lot of these characters. This is where the comparison to class-based shooters (like Team Fortress 2, Titanfall 2, Battlefield, etc) come in. In those games, the classes have their own unique "abilities" or "tools," much like heroes in games like Overwatch do, but you can still mold and bend these classes to your own playstyle via selectable tools and weapons. 
[b]2.[/b] In Overwatch 2, there are two types of character shortcomings. The first is that a lot of the characters feel... "niche" for a lack of better word. As in, you can feel like two (maybe even three) characters can be combined to create a more flexible and fun character with a much higher skill ceiling. The second is that Blizzard seemed to have actually kinda realized (maybe?) this issue, and tried to create a more "generalist" class, but again, due to the lack of meaningful customization, this just makes them a sort of "jack of all trades, master of none" character that makes them feel worthless. Not to mention Marvel Rivals does character variation kinda better, despite still suffering from the same issue by virtue of being a hero shooter.
[*]The "solo play vs team play" dilemma. Another thing that this game really fails at is being able to not just separate, but put in proper order when to mess around solo and when to actually play as a team. This comes via the ult system. When it comes to Overwatch, out of the gate you're pushed to play together as a team, letting tanks take the lead while the DPS spreads out (but not too far out) in order to create pressure from different angles, and the Support supports whoever needs the most support. But this is thrown out the window when a single player decides to use their ult. More often than not, these ults can completely break a well formed team push. Now, on paper this doesn't sound bad. Class-based games also have their own forms of stalemate breakers too. But the big issue is that there are some ults that require team cooperation, while others that can just screw the enemy team over on their own. This causes a break in momentum that most class based shooters don't have. A good example of this is the Medic's Ubercharge from TF2. It is very much a stalemate breaker ability that is activated by one player. Sounds similar to ults, right? But Ubercharges will forever be useless without team coordination. Fundamentally, the Medic literally cannot do anything offensive while Ubercharge is activated, and requires someone to be Ubercharged. Next, there is still the idea that Ubercharged players can be knocked back, so backup from the rest of the non-Ubercharged team is still required. This is what I mean by the "order" of things. In TF2 and Battlefield, you can just spread out and kinda just do your own thing, but when the time is right, the entire team needs to make a collective effort (that often tends to require very little communication surprisingly) to push. But in Overwatch, it's like a constant wave of needing teams and just outright spitting in the face of teamwork. It's confusing to say the least.
[/list]

[h1]Notes: [/h1]
[list]
[*]I won't be talking about the PvE Invasion thing since I didn't buy it and don't want to buy it (I'd rather fork over another $30 to Fortnite for a Miku skin, I'm being genuine rn), but from the let's plays I've seen and the criticisms levied towards it... I think it's safe to say TF2's Mann vs Machine is better.
[*]A lot of my criticisms definitely come from a place of my distaste for the "hero shooter" genre, so put this into consideration if you've read this far. My review mixes together both very biased views on the whole hero shooter schtick, but I also think I've provided some valid points to this game's not-so-great design.
[/list]

[h1]FINAL VERDICT: 4.3/10. MATPAT'S "GREGORY IS A ROBOT" THEORY ENDED UP BEING MORE RIGHT THAN HIS TF2 VS OVERWATCH VIDEO LOL. [/h1]

My honest steam review of Overwatch 2:

Recommended? Yes (but only if you enjoy pain, drama, and looking hot while losing)
Hours played: Too many. My sleep schedule left me in 2023 when my kid spawned.
Posted: From spawn, because I got dove again.

üíã ‚ÄúOverwatch 2 is less of a game and more of a psychological experiment where I, a humble Widow main, try to hold a lobby hostage with sheer vibes and pixel-perfect aim.‚Äù üíã

I load into every match dressed in latex, armed with a sniper rifle, and absolutely zero intention of touching the payload. I'm not here for teamplay. I'm here for the click. One shot. One kill. One team screaming ‚ÄúWIDOW SWITCH OMG.‚Äù

Do I switch?
Absolutely not.

Every match is the same:

Spawn in. Instantly sprint to the highest, least relevant rooftop.

Grapple into the sky like a majestic French bat.

Land a headshot so nasty the enemy Hanzo starts typing in Morse code.

Immediately get jumped by a Genji with the emotional stability of a breadstick.

Die in shame. Repeat.

Meanwhile, our support is deep in Narnia trying to 1v1 a flanking Cassidy (McCree for old schoolers), the tank is RPing as a Redditor with a hammer, and our Bastion is arguing with someone‚Äôs toaster in voice chat.

üíÄ "Widow diff" they say.
You're right. I am different. I‚Äôm not playing the same game as you. I‚Äôm playing Fashion Watch 2. Did you see my new skin? No? That‚Äôs because you were busy respawning. üíÖ

Pros:

High highs. Low moral accountability.

You look fabulous even while feeding.

That one headshot that erases someone‚Äôs will to live.

Grapple hook = mental reset button.

Cons:

One dive tank and it‚Äôs wrap city.

Your team will hate you no matter what.

You will be blamed for everything. Stubbed toe? Widow‚Äôs fault.

Final thoughts:
Overwatch 2 is not a game. It‚Äôs a battlefield of broken egos and shattered dreams. But I‚Äôll be damned if I‚Äôm not standing on top of it all, scoped in, with a 2% crit rate and a dream.

[I played on console for four years before finally getting a PC recently, hence the only "10 hrs played"]

There's honestly a lot to dislike about this game. The constant nerfing of characters that were never an issue, INSANELY overpriced shop items, and my control settings resetting when the feel like it are just a few. Nerfed most tanks into the ground---unless you like being a low-damage bullet sponge, play Damage. Wouldn't be surprised if they removed tanks from the game outright and just replaced them with 50-Shades-of-Mei (who btw so desparately needs to be debuffed). 

So why am I still recommending this? Cause it's fun to play; its a great game outside of the constant fumbling of nerfs and buffs. Its also free. You don't pay a dime to play this, and I'm kinda surprised they don't charge for it. I refuse to just give up when the character I play is debuffed, or when there's a $70 pack in the shop, so what? You don't have to buy it. Is it a sh*tty business practice? Yeah. Can we complain about it? Hell tf yeah. Maybe it's just me, but it's kinda crazy that THIS is the straw that broke the camels back for those who've played this forever. They gave us 6v6 mode back (AS COMP TOO) and they added a perk system that really allow you to have more control over your gameplay (ugh that sounded cheesy but still). Y'all complain when they don't change anything (i.e. pre Marvel Rivals era), and then y'all sigh and whine when they try improving and adding stuff to the game (i.e. perks, new characters, map voting system). You sure as heck got a right to complain, but I think this fan base has to work to define what it even wants in regard to... literally everything.

I‚Äôve been playing Overwatch since early 2018 and absolutely loved it for so many reasons. Fast forward to 2025, and after the disastrous launch of OW2 and all the surrounding drama, I can honestly say that in its current state, Overwatch 2 feels like the original, but with plenty of quality-of-life improvements, updates, and more content.

Earned loot boxes are back (and all your cosmetics carry over, of course), so I don‚Äôt feel any need to spend extra money to keep enjoying my mains. The game is frequently updated with new content and still includes nearly everything from the original (looking at you, CS2!), and retains that unique charm and gameplay I haven‚Äôt found in any other PvP shooter.

As someone who‚Äôs always played Overwatch casually rather than competitively, I find the community to be mostly positive, and the game consistently gives me a good time, more so than most multiplayer titles out there today.

All things considered, despite Blizzard‚Äôs past mistakes (and with "pro gamers" still finding reasons to complain), I genuinely think the devs deserve a second chance. The competition with Marvel Rivals seems to have pushed them in the right direction, and for the first time in years, I‚Äôm not only enjoying Overwatch again, I‚Äôm actually excited to see what comes next.

Personally, Overwatch 1 > Overwatch 2. Had the most fun and best memories on OW1 and with 1k hours on OW2 it was never as good and never will be and has only gotten worse for me with every update and corp choices (sold to Microsoft/Activision). Blizzard even before being sold was always very shady and betraying its community by promising lies to convince people to accept OW2, killing OWL, making it pay to win as at the start the new characters were locked behind the battlepass and with them being completely broken on release every time, and just the way it treats its community in general and the automated report system that has wrongfully banned many with Terms and Conditions that let them do what they want with you having no power to fight anything. Will stop playing this game as I got my best from the version killed, and try to find a new Hero shooter or competitive game to fall in love with. 

Generally for a new player (casual and competitive) I still wouldn't recommend this game, its very hard to get into and get good at with how the characters, Meta and maps are made. Besides that, there is no guarantee for the future of the game with it belonging to Microsoft/Activision, once it stops making a certain amount of money, the longevity of the game as well as its updates and improvements will significantly slow unless it gets cut off or replaced entirely.  Better to put your eggs in the basket that guarantees the games longevity no matter the financial situation such new as Marvel Rivals (Developer commitment: NetEase has stated their goal to support the game for at least 10 years, which Overwatch hasn't promised even a year let alone a decade), or something older such as Paladins (very loved by its community) or even something a lot more different and difficult such as Valorant (strong community, quite the big E sports scene and it with a similar ecosystem as they are even making their own MMO).

TDLR: I do not recommend anyone to play this, it's dead (OW1 my beloved), balancing is far bellow what to be expected of such a long running game,  new content is mostly skins and promotions that costs insane amount (Only battlepass is worth it), will not have a strong future (5 and 10+ years) and character design and release has been flawed and weak since Echo. Besides that, low quality artwork and content for fans to engage with, if any of it is made is mid-tier fan art quality being generous.

after putting some time into this game, not alot but some, i can say it has its strong points, and its negatives, lets start with the positives. there is SO much content as a new player, such as the stadium game mode, ranked which isnt that hard to get (can be good and bad) and the fact a lot of the people you meet are very cool. now for the negatives, there are a few heros which will get on your nerves if you are first playing this game (sombra, wrecking ball) but sombra is usually banned in lower ranks (not sure about higher) and wrecking ball is easily counterable once learned. your queues for ranked if you are trying to play as a damage in role queue can be horrendassly long at lower ranks (again, not sure about higher), and dont let the steam charts fool you, 8 out of 10 pc players play on battle.net.

my conclusion is, is that you should give overwatch a try, unlock ranked and get your rank, then you'll know if you like it or not from there.

I was a massive fan of Overwatch, but like many others I completely dropped the game when "Overwatch 2" was released, as they ruined so much of the game.

Now some years later, the Overwatch team has taken big steps to improving the mess that was "Overwatch 2", and when I heard that they brought back lootboxes, and made it possible to actually gain some stuff in-game without having to deal with the battlepass, I decided to give the game another shot.

And it turns out that gameplay wise, they have absolutely managed to surpass the original "Overwatch", and the balancing seems so much better now. And they've added a lot of fun characters (like Ramattra). They've also recently been running some "classic" modes based on specific times in Overwatch's history (like the GOATS meta) for their anniversary event, where you've felt how awful the balancing was back during those times. I thought it'd be great to play those modes, but I just felt miserable playing that and wanted to go back playing the OW2 modes instead.

At this point, I do feel like the game does deserve to get a slightly better rating on Steam. Not saying they deserve a really good rating, but at least a mixed position. It is a fun game to play, but the fact still remains that they did screw up hard, and needs to keep working to improve the game. Personally I'm still really salty that the Archives missions from the original game are gone, as they're claiming that they broke because of the "new" engine, and that they killed the PVE campaign.

It's also about time that they made it possible to buy old battlepasses, and make them possible to complete whenever, because this FOMO crap needs to go away. Plus they really need to reduce the price of shop skins. It'd just ridiculous how expensive they are.

But overall it's now a fun game again to play a little from time to time.

[h3] Honestly, one of the most polished experiences available since 2016. [/h3]

Despite promising a PvE mode and not delivering on it, and despite the absurd cosmetic prices, they‚Äôve continued to release updates throughout the years. 

There are still new original heroes, new modes, and plenty of quality-of-life improvements.

I must say there's a lot of hate on this game but honestly if you put in the time and effort to better yourself, pick up a few teammates along the way and climb the ranks in various different game modes it can be a lot of fun. It has come along way with the added bonus of augments, a fun new twist to the game, new heroes, skins and more content being released regularly that keeps me coming back for more. yeah sure you can jump up and down about the campaign not being released but seriously what got you hooked on OW in the first place, competitive, diverse, intense and strategic game play. OW2 has provided stunning graphics and preforms well almost all the time. one thing to note is us Aussies have to deal with region hopping issues causing latency potentially throwing all hope out the window. stop the hate and open your eyes on just how beautiful this game has become and will only continue to improve.
The game has made huge improvements and I can honestly recommend it now!
Don't know why people trash on this game, sure the community sucks but the gameplay is fun and addicting and you can get some pretty cool skins for free!

I could get really good with a handful of characters I enjoy playing and do that and actually have fun. Title: OVERWATCH 2 IS THE BIGGEST BETRAYAL IN GAMING HISTORY ‚Äî I‚ÄôM ACTUALLY SHAKING

Let me be perfectly clear: Overwatch 2 is not a game. It‚Äôs a scam with a user interface. Blizzard took one of the most creative, team-focused shooters ever made and murdered it in cold blood, then had the audacity to call the corpse a sequel.

They lied. They straight-up lied for YEARS. PvE? DEAD. Story mode? DEAD. Hero progression? NEVER EXISTED. They stood on stage, made promises, took the hype, took the money ‚Äî and then said ‚Äúoops, we changed our minds.‚Äù NO accountability. NO shame. NO care for the community that built this franchise.

And now what do we have? A game that‚Äôs barely functional. The matchmaking is pure chaos ‚Äî you either steamroll or get demolished. There is no skill balance, no fairness, no reason to even queue. It feels like Blizzard is actively trying to make the experience as miserable as possible.

Heroes? BROKEN. Every patch breaks something else. They don‚Äôt even pretend to test anymore. You can feel the laziness oozing through every update. It‚Äôs like they spin a wheel labeled ‚ÄúRANDOM BALANCE CHANGES‚Äù and call it a day.

And the monetization? It‚Äôs predatory garbage. They took every greedy corporate trick in the book and shoved it into this thing. Twenty. Dollars. For. ONE. Skin. You remember when we used to earn skins by playing? Yeah, Blizzard remembers too ‚Äî and they decided fun was unprofitable.

Now it‚Äôs all about the Battle Pass of Misery‚Ñ¢, where you grind for hours just to unlock a voice line you‚Äôll never use. The shop is a clown fiesta of overpriced junk. It‚Äôs insulting, it‚Äôs shameless, it‚Äôs disgusting.

I am so angry I can‚Äôt even type straight. Overwatch 2 is the definition of corporate greed ‚Äî a Frankenstein monster made of false promises, lazy design, and pure disrespect. Blizzard didn‚Äôt just ruin a game ‚Äî they violated the trust of an entire community.

The worst part? They act like they did us a favor. Like we should be grateful for this disaster. No. Absolutely not. Overwatch 2 isn‚Äôt a sequel. It‚Äôs a soulless parasite sucking the life out of what once was great.

FINAL SCORE: Solid 7/10.

This game is awful. RNG to get good teammates entirely determines matches. You constantly get terrible random teammates while playing against 4mans+. The projectile size buff was terrible making it where you dont even have to visually hit the character to get a hitmarker. Ranked mode is entirely based off of match wins so even if you carry your team to a win you get no extra ranking. There is also a constant "predicted" that shows up reducing your ranking progress. There r a few characters in the game that r just extremely annoying to play against bc they take pretty much no skill to use. The people that play them will play like rats to get a kill while not even helping their team on objective. 

If you want a game where you r entirely dependent on your team to be able to get a win to go up in rank (which with this metric you can pretty much be carried by a good team so rank effectively means nothing) then this game is for you.

The only thing good I can say about this game in terms of a cross-platform FPS is that it IS CROSS-PLATFORM anf that the air assist isnt INSANELY strong nor do you have aim assist at all on PC when on controller. So it is at least competitive when it comes to controller vs M&K.

Once you start living in Korea you automatically start playing it.

It's fun, so feel free to play it. At the time of this review and between accounts I collectively have accumulated about 2,500 hours since OW1 in 2016.

However, all of the skins are outrageously expensive. It's sickening to think a gun skin can cost $40. Or certain collab/universe mixes can easily be $120+.

Battle pass is more reasonable and fair. You'll also get enough in-game credit (prisms) to get one mythic skin, which some are really cool and change both VFX/SFX for your gameplay. 

Don't give into FOMO.
Don't enable overpriced, predatory MTX practices.
Don't ever let Blizzard get away with the OW2 history, lies, and fiasco.
Don't engage with player toxicity (as you see in every online game) because you can get banned for anything. Yes, anything. It's not worth engaging. The bar for a ban is very low. Turn off all text and voice chat. I'm not exaggerating and yes I've experienced multiple temp bans or account silences ranging from being tilted, being toxic, and neutrally criticizing someones attitude, gameplay, or suggesting something politely. 

However, at the end of the day, with Stadium and Perks implemented, the gameplay is fun, dynamic, and provides good challenge and fun. Most of the time.

Play the game and buy a battlepass to support ongoing development. Don't give money anywhere else.

This game is like that ex of yours - you know the one; the one you sometimes think about as you get ready to go to your lonely bed for the night. The one where things didn't work out just due to bad timing. Maybe you weren't ready for a commitment yet, maybe they came on a little too strong and asked for too much too soon. You should call them... It wasn't a toxic relationship, it was just miscommunication, right? Your friends loved them, your family loved them, what was so bad?

And as you lay there, you decide to hit them up again. They oblige, and before you know it, the two of you get back into your familiar rhythm. You make the same jokes, you have the same interests... But time has passed for both of you - you've both matured as individuals. You're both mostly the same people, but with small little variations. For example, you took on more responsibility at work, so you don't have quite as much free time to line up with their schedule. She's moved into a totally new neighborhood, and as much as it's easier to see them now, you're not sure you like how close they are to some of your friends... and somehow, eventually, those small differences start to sow doubt and mistrust between you two. Despite knowing each other for years, you start to feel like total strangers to each other. Finally, after far longer than you're willing to admit, you start to remember why you broke up. All the frustrations, the little things that used to drive you crazy, it's all still there. You break up (again), and swear you'll never go back (again).

But before you know it, the rose tinted goggles are back, and you repeat the cycle. You get ready for bed one night, and think fondly of all the time the two of you used to spend together... you should really call them...

This is the second-oldest good Hero shooter; the first one is Team Fortress 2. The only problem this game has is that it‚Äôs created by¬†Blizzard, the worst anti-consumer company you can imagine. After the Marval Rival launched, this game has suffered in comparison as Rival is a successor to what the OW2 was supposed to be for Overwatch. But Blizzard turns down their¬†anti-consumer tricks a little less to get more playerbase, which I give them some credit for. I joined OW2 in the first session and saw their predatory monetization when there was no actual good competitor. I left after the first session, but loved the core gameplay. I have joined S18 to see why everyone is saying it's not that bad anymore. People and Stremer are right, it‚Äôs in a way better state, but not as good as the Marvel Rival Level in monetization, but going in a good direction. If you can ignore the¬†monetization part or just want to play for free, it‚Äôs a good game, but I like to support games that I like, so it‚Äôs decent for me at the moment. 

[b] A few things they can do to fix the¬†monetization - [/b]
[list]
 [*] Make the Battlepass not expire if you bought it, like Marvel Rival. 
 [*] Battlepass should give 100 Mythic coins in BP, as every mythic skin, if you want to unlock the full set, it costs around 100. 
 [*] Weapon inspect should be the default for every hero. for the mythic gun, it should add another inspect for the gun.
[/list]

A once unique experience that got ruined for a live-service model that ruined the user experience. I'll just leave my thoughts below after 2k hours since the Overwatch 1 beta days. 

- Matchmaking is down right awful. I don't know why the matchmaking in this game feels like it needs to punish solo Q players. No I don't always blame my team for losses. I know it sometimes my fault that I could have played better, but why does Blizzard find it acceptable to match me against the same 3-6 stack every match? If you solo Q and there happens to be a stack in your region you're going to see them non-stop in competitive. The matchmaking does not stop for a second to think, "Mhhh this guy has played against this same group for 3 matches in a row and we keep giving him the same random team, surely we should look for an alternative match? Nah 4th time is the charm." Getting placed on the apposite side of a 3-6 stack team wouldn't be such a bad thing if people decided to use mics and communicate with each other. But this is Overwatch in 2025 were talking about, everyone who plays this game is anti-social and has social anxiety.  Just saying a simple "Hello" in VC is such a daunting task for anyone in this game that they'd rather get backshots from the enemy stack than communicating. But when things go bad everyone types 500 Words per minute and flame the tank and DPS. If 10% of this community applied themselves in any other aspect in their life I am convinced we would solve most modern problems like a cure for cancer, world hunger, and global conflict. But these degenerates rather be spending 12 hours a day bad mouthing other players for a singular mistake and never look in the mirror. Oh and Mercy players... you all ain't cute and think your the main character because you hold left click and occasionally fly around pressing shift. I hate you the most because you contribute nothing and blame everyone else for your failures.  

- Stadium caters to all the characters that sell skins and leave them broken for months on end until. They nerfed Freja in less than a week after being put in stadium but continue to let a character like D.va have the ability of having a broken dumb builds is beyond annoying. Which one do you think is selling more skins? 

- The dev team preaches about creating a safe-space for the community, but over the last 5-6 months in my ranked matches I see p*do jokes, racism, sexism, and even had a couple instances of hearing terms thrown at minority groups in VC. You'd think they get banned right? Nah I still see them in my diamond-low master lobbies. But they banned a guy for saying "Noob." There's the morale compass this team believes in, only after getting called out did they deem "Noob" was fine like all the other racist, sexism, and other stuff I hear and read in game. The report system barely works and has been known to wrongfully ban players with Blizzard support basically telling them "Sorry you're out of luck." Oh and its perfectly fine to brag about smurfing in this game, the devs and report system don't really care. Only way action gets taken against players is when mass-reporting happens to an account and the automated system does the job blizzard is to lazy to do. If a stack of players decide to report you than your account gets flagged and eventually can lead to an undeserved ban. 

- Balancing philosophy is stupid, I'm convinced there's not a single person on the dev team who is above silver 5. They hear about broken characters and just change very minor things like -/+ .5 seconds off an ability and never address why a character is broken or annoying to play against. Kiri hardly ever gets touched because you can't touch the golden children in this game...

- The skin economy is beyond stupid in this game. You can guarantee three characters are going to get skins every season. Kiri, Juno, and Mercy. Not just a "Skin" no I mean "Skins." You like a certain character that isn't gooner friendly? Well I hope you enjoy grinding loot boxes for some old OW1 cosmetics and OW2 season passes skins so that you can MAYBE get that characters skin. This dev team better be thankful for all the gooners this community has because allot of them would be homeless and out of a job. (Just look at Mercy's persona collab skin.) Oh and if your favorite character doesn't sell skins then they'll never buff them to make them as viable as other characters. Kiri never gets touched despite the community wanting changes to her Suzu, Damage, and TP. She sells so its fine to leave her in a unbalanced way. 

- If a person who enjoys Overwatch hears you say "They didn't deliver on any of the promises they said about OW2" they'll tell ya to move on. Honestly, you guys are whats wrong about live-service games. I spent money for the original release of the game in OW1 and it got taken away from people like me who actually misses the developers pouring their actual love into this franchise. Now you're just a wallet for them to keep scamming. Yeah Jeff could have made the transition easier, but you can't tell me OW2 isn't a downgrade from OW1 in its current state. 

- They introduced a ban and map voting system. While I think this is the one positive change this game has done, lets not kid ourselves and say this wasn't because of RIvals bringing competition to the market. They could've done this earlier and implemented features the community has been wanting for years, but all is forgiven because now it has a direct competitor? Nahhhhhh its scummy and insulting. This game was printing money because every game that tried to compete with them sucked and there wasn't a decent alternative. 

- Every new character they come out with has little to no soul attached to them. The last two characters they came out with that had any semblance of being cool and unique was Ramattra and Junker Queen. Actual characters that had some story and awesome design. Since then? 

[list]
    [*]Kiriko - A cliche anime shaped character with a back story that contradicts what little lore this game has. 
    [*]Lifeweaver - A hyper flirtatious guy with roses...
    [*]Illari - Such a fumbled character, an interesting premise and back story that they never expanded because she doesn't sell.
    [*]Mauga - Hey lets put Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson in our game... oh he said no? Give him two miniguns and some hair so people wont notice.
    [*]Venture - They eat rocks, isn't that funny guys? Lets forget they ever existed and not throw her skins for a few seasons... takes away resources for our female characters.
    [*]Juno - Another generic anime figure who lacks any social awareness. Oh she's an astronaut? Lets make every new skin for her non space-themed and more gooner friendly. 
    [*]Hazard - Oh people really liked the concept artwork before this new dev team took over? Nah that's to original. Just make him generically buff with spikes. 
    [*]Freja - Another boring designed character. But this time lets give her a personality that matches her design. 
    [*]Wuyang - Honestly just feels like the dev team said "Lets take Juno and Kiriko and just make them into a guy." His kit is unique I'll give them that, but like majority of the new characters made its just another fucking boring anime inspired character. 
[/list] 

Yes this game is addicting, but its really hindered by a greedy dev team that doesn't really care about making it better. Only reason we saw changes the last year is because another game decided to copy its formula and do somethings better and a group of the community wanting to jump ship. If you want to play it then go for it, but just turn off voice/text chat because the community is worse than the actual people in charge of the game.

Let me sit you down and tell you a story about love, pain, and pixelated betrayal. This ain't just about a video game, sugar‚Äîthis is about a lifestyle. A spiritual journey. A battle between good and evil that plays out every night on my monitor with more drama than a Tennessee divorce court. It‚Äôs called Overwatch, and it has chewed me up, spit me out, and left me cryin‚Äô on the kitchen floor with a cold cup of coffee and a disconnected headset.

Now, I‚Äôve been playin‚Äô this game since God was a child. From payloads to control points, from quick play to comp hell‚ÄîI‚Äôve seen it all. And the one thing that ain‚Äôt changed? My teammates still play like they‚Äôre tryin‚Äô to sabotage me on purpose. I swear, every time I solo queue it‚Äôs like Blizzard spun a wheel labeled "NPC Behavior" and slapped five randos together who collectively couldn‚Äôt read a mini-map if it was tattooed on their foreheads.

I got tanks with zero brain activity, supports off on spiritual retreats in Narnia, and DPS players who think they‚Äôre on America‚Äôs Next Top Widowmaker‚Äîposin‚Äô instead of shootin'. It‚Äôs a hot mess, and I‚Äôm the poor soul tryna duct tape it together with heals, callouts, and one single strand of hope I keep in my sock drawer.

Now let‚Äôs talk about the real scandal‚ÄîKiriko. Oh baby. Kiriko out here livin‚Äô her best anime girl fantasy. She‚Äôs got a new skin every four business minutes. Battle pass skin? Kiriko. Mythic skin? Kiriko. Limited-time event? You guessed it‚ÄîKiriko in another flawlessly tailored outfit that makes her look like she just stepped off the set of a magical girl reboot and onto my kill feed.

Meanwhile, my girls Symmetra and Echo? They sittin‚Äô over there like extras in a budget sci-fi movie, wearin‚Äô the same dusty outfits since launch. No updates. No love. Just silence. And I say this with every ounce of respect‚Äîwhere the hell are my thigh-highs and latex body suits?

Yes, you heard me right.

I want Symmetra struttin‚Äô into battle lookin‚Äô like a futuristic dominatrix who builds sentry turrets by day and breaks hearts by night. I want Echo glidin‚Äô through the air in a glossy, black latex bodysuit, high heels clickin‚Äô in the kill cam like she‚Äôs about to drop an electro-pop album on her way to a 5K. Give her LED trim, high-fashion lines, and the audacity of a villainess in a cyberpunk novella. You gave Kiriko a streetwear collab and Cassidy a gun made of lava‚Äîdon‚Äôt tell me this is too much to ask.

I‚Äôm talkin‚Äô full glam. I‚Äôm talkin‚Äô style that could kill before the ult even hits. I want Symmetra with a side slit and Echo with wings dipped in chrome and attitude. Put some lace on those thigh-highs. Put some vengeance in their eyes. Let these women slay on the battlefield and on the runway. Don‚Äôt be shy, Blizzard. We‚Äôve seen what you‚Äôre capable of. Give the girls what they deserve.

And don‚Äôt try to feed me another recolor from 2018. I want the devs to feel slightly ashamed and also very proud when they hit ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù on these skins. I want a Twitter debate. I want fan art. I want my matches interrupted because the enemy team stopped to admire Echo‚Äôs latex-fitted wing plating.

Meanwhile, the game itself? Still a mess. Ranked is as busted as a gas station microwave. Balance? A fever dream. I‚Äôve seen Moiras with 20k damage and 4k healing, Junkrats who think the floor is lava, and Hanzos who couldn‚Äôt hit a barn if it was sittin‚Äô on their nose. Every other patch feels like someone at Blizzard is just tossin‚Äô changes in a cauldron like it‚Äôs potion night at Hogwarts.

And still, despite the chaos, the heartbreak, and the emotional damage‚ÄîI log in. I queue up. I pick my mains, pop my cooldowns, and carry teams like I‚Äôm draggin‚Äô a pack of overcooked biscuits through the mud. Why? Because deep down, I still love this trainwreck of a game. I still believe.

But Blizzard‚Ä¶ baby‚Ä¶ give me latex. Give me thigh-highs. Give me divine justice for the girls you left behind.

Until then, I‚Äôll be on the payload, wearin‚Äô imaginary couture, mutin‚Äô my teammates, and prayin‚Äô that one day, Echo‚Äôs wings won‚Äôt just be functional‚Äîthey‚Äôll be fierce.

Amen. GG. And let Symmetra serve, not just shields‚Äîbut looks.

Finally in a worth-while, playable state - Overwatch 2 at its best is a beautiful, diverse ecosystem of constants and variables smoothly interacting with each other, each organism working alongside one another to reach the logical conclusion of an encounter - victory or defeat.  If you like hero shooters, I say go ahead and give it a shot - but with ONE trade off.

Blizzard is an absolutely evil company. Do not give them money. Give them some time, but never money. Leave that to the Mercy, Kiriko, Juno, and now Wuyang simps who will buy every overpriced 40$ skin at launch. As long as you do not give this game money, it's fine.

Not at all the Overwatch 2 that was promised, and it isn't good enough to compensate.


-No player agency. The game is team reliant to a disgusting degree. You are nothing without your team, and thus you are completely at the mercy of randos in order to play the video game whatsoever.

-Worst matchmaking on the planet by design. If you are on a winning streak you are purposefully paired with braindead animals for the next 2-6 games.

-Horrible balancing, just as it was in OW1. The only difference is now the devs respond to *some* feedback *slightly* quicker. Even with that, some heroes with huge leads in ban/win/pick rates are completely ignored by devs-- some of which being ignored for upwards of 7 years with no major changes/reworks. Additionally the power-creep seen over the past few years and giving almost every character more movement abilities has been really sad to see.

-Horribly toxic and defensive community. Everyone is on edge at all times, even in quick play. Ranked is a complete nightmare full of entitled morons that are looking for any excuse to relay 10,000 slurs in chat after throwing the game for their team.

-No good answer to counterswapping. If any of the tanks in the game are your favorite characters in the game, enjoy getting counterswapped after getting one kill on an enemy. If you're playing D.va and the enemy goes Zarya, or if you're playing Winston and the enemy goes Reaper, or if you're playing Roadhog and literally anyone swaps at all-- well sorry I guess you just can't play that character anymore unless you're okay with throwing the entire match.

-Reduction of the core game to 5v5. This exacerbates the counterswapping issues mentioned above because half of the tanks were never designed to be the main characters in a match. You also lose out on a large amount of unique gameplay scenarios and combos that 6v6 provided. But because Blizzard didn't know how to balance it they just literally removed a player slot.

-Integral competitive features coming far too late. Only recently getting hero bans, the ability to see weapon/ability stats, and map voting after 9 years of Overwatch being released is a joke; even the state those features are in are unsatisfying and bare-bones.

-Only one badly priced, uninteresting PVE campaign with no talents/perk system as promised.

-Predatory monetization with a new 30 dollar Mercy skin bundle released every week. It was much worse on launch with new heroes being paywalled, but even in it's current state it's still a joke.

-Loot boxes. They reversed their decision to remove loot boxes as a way to appease players and give a more enticing reward for events; but the current iteration gives you complete garbage and no basically rewards for duplicates whatsoever.

-Godawful writing and "lore." I don't even need to expand on the "lore" bit since there basically is none, and for writing just listen to Venture speak once and you'll know what I mean.

-Optimization gets worse every single patch no matter what rig you're running, and every new patch introduces numerous bugs throughout all aspects of the game.


Recently there are two large gameplay additions that are supposed to renew player interest in the game; those being the perks system and the stadium mode. So let me talk about those a bit:

-Perks are this game's system of an item shop or talent system in the core game. You earn EXP by contributing to the match and can choose a couple talents to improve or modify your character's playstyle. This was made to disincentivize counter-swapping. Unfortunately realistically what it boils down to is that the team that starts with a lead (which most likely is the team the game calculated to be the winner during matchmaking) can more easily hold the lead and snowball easier, especially since if anyone on the losing team swaps their EXP resets to 0 for the new character. Some of the perks also re-introduce CC that was previously removed due to overwhelming negative player feedback such as Mei being able to freeze enemies again... ??? Who on earth thought this was a good idea???

-Stadium is a mode that literally does not allow players to swap, and instead can (in theory) build their characters in vastly differently ways each round in order to potentially play around the enemies or their own team. However the execution is pretty botched, the items you can buy almost have no noticeable effect on the game until the last couple rounds (you can buy 5% attack speed...Wow!!!). If the items were slightly more impactful I don't think I would have much of an issue-- the real problem is again the horrendous matchmaking that purposefully pairs you with braindead swines that don't know how to read or use a computer. And now you're stuck in an even longer match with them.


In conclusion: this game is trash.

So, I never played Overwatch 1. When I first started playing ow2, you had to unlock a vast majority of the characters, which kinda sucked. And then, at some point, they made you start with all of those characters, which was a very welcome change. Since then, I've seen the game continue to go mostly upwards, Sure, there's been a few changes that people hated (road rework, sombra rework), but they've been genuinely listening to their players now and reverting things or changing them to a point that people like. They released Stadium, which, while not totally my vibe, is welcome by many others. They also added 6v6 back, which (while I can't comment on how it compares to OW1 6v6), its fun. Fair, I'm not super high ranked, so I don't feel the pain of long queue times (average q time is about 1 or 2 minutes, max for both qp and ranked). I am almost never stuck as a solo tank in 6v6, and the community has been rather nice. I don't get yelled at (er, well, mostly not), and when I do, uh, its fair. No one wants a doomfist that falls off the map. Every minute. 

Moving on, though, the hero design always impresses me. Skins are good, but the actual gameplay feels smooth and I never feel like I reached the skill cap of that particular character, Doomfist always has more I can learn, both in terms of techs but also how to use his movement better. Unlike some other games, where the abilities are super 1 dimensional, this is nice. I can keep learning, instead of just getting better at aiming and being in the right position. 

8/10, good game. Theres room to improve, but its free and fun. I can't really explain.

As of writing (Oct 2025) the game is currently in the best state it's ever been. Finally, after almost two years of dragging their feet it's finally easy to earn cosmetics for free and the new Stadium mode is the most fun I've ever had with the franchise.

I will however state that the 'Invasion' bundle is a straight up scam, PLEASE do not buy this. The fact Blizzard is continuing to sell a product that you can't even find real people to play with or complete the highest difficulty at all without a premade group is borderline criminal, it's simply not the product they are advertising and charging people for.

This game has improved so much since the OW2 release incident. I stopped playing around 2020 and came back this year when LSF collab was announced. And to my surprise, this game is worth staying. New game mode, Stadium, is so much fun if you're actually trying to do something unusual and winning the game even if your team drafts are worse than your opponents. So much fun events, arcade modes, lootboxes, and I really feel the devs are trying so much to make this game cool and popular again.

Have many more hours on xbox, am new to pc. This game has lots of controversy to the crowd that purchased overwatch 1 for good reason; lying about features that would be in the sequel for money..

However, as it stands, for any new players interested in shooters this game is a must-try. It's completely free to download, and you dont have to pay to unlock heroes. Recent updates have shown that Blizzard are listening to the community, for example with the return of free skins from lootboxes. 

Gameplay variety is huge, and cosmetics are great.

The negative rating and hate Overwatch 2 has is very misleading for a new player. The game runs well and is genuinely fun. It's the best hero shooter I've played and has updates all the time, though some more map variety would be nice. I'm sure the game was even better in the past according to what people say, but as someone that joined right as it went free to play I've never had any issues with it.
