I've played this game almost entirely - since release - as pharah, then genji a while after overwatch 2 came out. I always appreciated the custom controls and reticles after they were released. I have an issue using my preferred method of input now that I have yet to find a remedy to. 

I dont know why they changed things from how they were but I used to be able to play with controller in my left hand, for movement, and some buttons, and mouse in my right hand for aim, and a few buttons. 

A few patches ago I was suddenly unable to play pharah entirely because I couldnt "hover" with the thrusters any more. Now, I cant play any characters with my setup because the game doesnt allow a seamless switch between controller and mouse during play. It used to be able to be "fixed" by forcing the ui to display either keyboard or mouse only, which would get rid of the ui changing back and forth every movement/flick of the mouse, but now you just cannot use both at all. 

I dont understand the necessity of changing things that have never been an issue. there has been nothing introduced that I can tell that necessitates changing this function whatsoever. Overwatch has been on a steady decline since before ow2, since before jeff left, before goats meta etc - and this is just the final drop in the bucket for me. I quit for over a year when they went back on their promises for pve and made it clear they had no intention of developing that + started pushing out inane character designs with ai-generated ass identities and stories. Now I just came back to play the damn ninja. I cant even do that any more.

I like this game. People complain a lot about Blizzard being money hungry, but the game is free, and I've been free2play so far and have been having plenty of fun. I wouldn't say it's pay to win, most definitely. it seems like everything you pay for is just optional customization. 
And if you disable in-game chat you can just have a fun time and won't even catch shit from toxic players. Custom games and playing with big groups of people is especially fun, and I have really enjoyed the most recent seasons.

Overwatch has been one of the few games that got me hooked into the PVP genre, and i've been playing it since 2017,  Switching over to this brand new type of game since playing Call of duty was fun and enjoyable, i made tons of friends and absolutely loved this game, but stopped right after the announcement of role-que and eventually quit.

Ever since then i have tried numerous games like Rocket League, Apex Legends and R6 Siege to capture what overwatch was once to me. However there never was the feeling in any other game of coming back home after a busy day and just playing Overwatch until you pass out and there never will be.

Since both the announcement of a sequel and the questionable turn it took at its launch, i tried it once again, this time "Overwatch 2" and although it had a huge change in monetisation and game mode changes, It was still harbouring the same "Overwatch" i enjoyed but since then a lot of promises have been broken, and a lot of bad decisions have been made no doubt, and i quit once again, At the time i never enjoyed it as much as i did and i felt like the game had taken too much time or changed way too much in certain ways for me to replicate that feeling again.

Then i took a long break and I finally came back very recently and found myself excited for every match i play, even if we won or lost i still had absolute fun the past few weeks playing this game again. Loot Boxes are back, Currency is easy to earn and there's tons of events at every corner to keep you busy. Overwatch 2 has never been more fun for me and i think that was the biggest realization I've come to is that the game at its core is still what i personally find the most enjoyable so far. even in the current sea of games and most importantly i didn't need to replicate that exact feeling i had i just need to keep having fun with newer ones.

To anyone who wants to try this game, absolutely do it. To anyone who was promised a lot of things and never got them, i completely understand you and i hate it too and don't blame you. To anyone who gets pissed off or slowly get uninterested, Take a break, no matter how long and come back again. and to all of you, just try to have a fun time no matter what. that's how i enjoy this game and I'm excited to keep playing more towards the future till the very end.

As a long time Paladins player turned refugee as support for the game is being cut, Overwatch isn't bad.

Is the aggressive monetization of this game annoying and predatory? Yes. Is it egregious and disappointing that the entire selling point of this "sequel," the PvE, was scrapped? Yes. Is the community toxic and unbearable? Eh, depends on what circles you hang around in; in my experience? No. Is the game dying? If you think 30k concurrent players is "dead," then sure.

Honestly, all I care about is if the game is fun. As someone who played OG Overwatch back in 2017, lost interest after the hard pivot towards competitive-first balancing and continual dip in content around 2019, and rejoined the fray this year, I honestly think the game is in one of the best spots its been in terms of pure gameplay. The balancing is not perfect of course, but I rarely feel like the game is unfair to the point of being frustrated. I literally do not care that it's 5v5 now, the team dynamic is still enjoyable even in quick play. The influx of new content is exciting, even if it's a lot of cosmetic items. I'm glad that loot boxes are purely obtained via progression and aren't just straight up gambling, and that the option exists to buy skins directly, as they are still ultimately cosmetic and don't have any impact on gameplay. 

So, is Overwatch 2 fun in the year of our Lord 2025? Yeah. So I recommend it. It's free, why the heck not at least try it out?

Overwatch 2 is what happens when a great game gets dragged out of its grave, hollowed out, and stuffed full of microtransactions. Calling this a sequel is like putting a new sticker on an old toaster and charging triple the price ‚Äî it‚Äôs insulting, lazy, and frankly embarrassing for Blizzard Entertainment.

The switch from 6v6 to 5v5 was supposed to ‚Äúevolve‚Äù the gameplay. Instead, it nuked the balance and left matches feeling like chaotic messes where one bad tank can single-handedly ruin the game. Tanks are now glorified punching bags with identity crises, supports exist to be target practice, and DPS are still playing Call of Duty in the corner.

And the monetization? It‚Äôs a joke ‚Äî a greedy, tone-deaf joke. Skins that used to be earned through actual gameplay now cost more than entire indie games. The ‚Äúfree-to-play‚Äù label is just a fancy way of saying ‚Äúpay us to have fun.‚Äù It‚Äôs less a shooter and more a shopping mall with guns.

The biggest insult of all, though, is the gutted PvE mode. Blizzard dangled it in front of fans for years like a carrot, then ripped it away and handed us a sad, watered-down mission system that barely qualifies as content. It‚Äôs bait-and-switch at its finest.

Underneath all the corporate nonsense, the Overwatch 1 DNA is still there ‚Äî and that‚Äôs the only reason this game is remotely playable. But everything new Overwatch 2 tries is either worse, broken, or painfully cash-grabby.

Final Verdict: This isn‚Äôt a sequel ‚Äî it‚Äôs a glorified update wrapped in a cash shop and sprinkled with broken promises.
‚≠êÔ∏è 2/10 ‚Äî Overwatch 2 is less a game and more a cautionary tale about how to ruin your own legacy.

[h1] Love the World, Hate Everything Else [/h1]

Honestly, it‚Äôs a 50/50 for me. I‚Äôve been obsessed with Overwatch lore and characters since before OW2 launched, so when I heard it was going to be free-to-play, I jumped in right away.

The downside? It‚Äôs Blizzard. And sadly, that shows. Every cosmetic feels insanely overpriced especially collabs (skins from collabs shouldn't cost more than the game it's from!) like you‚Äôre paying a kidney and an eyeball just for a basic skin that doesn‚Äôt even look that good.

Balance is also all over the place. Some characters definitely feel favored in terms of how strong they are, while newer heroes often feel powercrept or just not as viable. It can make matches feel frustrating and uneven.

I still love the universe, and the core gameplay can be fun, but between the monetization and the balancing issues, it‚Äôs hard to stay invested long-term.

Overwatch 2 Review: Worse Than a Walk in the Park

One day I went to the park, touched grass, saw kids playing tag, and realized it had better balance and teamwork than Overwatch 2. At least in tag nobody‚Äôs paying $20 to cosplay as Kiriko, a hero who‚Äôs already mid to begin with.

Blizzard deleted Overwatch 1 just to sell us a downgrade with overpriced skins and zero soul. I‚Äôd rather watch pigeons fight over breadcrumbs than queue another match.

Well, here it is, my review for Overwatch 2 (OW2). Note that my playtime on Steam isn't accurate, as I play on the Battle . NET version a lot more (my Career Profile states I have 1,854 hours in-game, but that probably doesn't count menus and was probably reset from OW1 to OW2). I have been playing Overwatch since the first game, and before Season 1 of Competitive Play was even a thing, I'm from the old times.

Honestly, this game is what many people have always asked from Triple-A game developers. A Free to Play game where the only monetization is behind cosmetics, and NOT gameplay mechanics. Now, I will give a brief history that this wasn't always the case, and I'm glad that Blizzard / Activision has decided to step back with some of their earlier decisions when OW2 was released.

In this actual Free to Play game, you have a variety of heroes to choose from, Damage heroes, Tank heroes, and Support heroes. Each one of them feel very unique, and as how matches go, think of Team Fortress 2 (TF2) but with MOBA mechanics. You have abilities on cooldown, you got Ultimates, and so on. Unlike MOBAs, you can switch heroes at anytime, at the cost of a % of your Ultimate charge. Recently, they also added "Perks", that you unlock during gameplay per match, and you equip them on-the-fly. It's a great system that makes matches feel more different and more varied.

Netcode feels very good overall, and I don't have any issues with it. In the early days of OW2, and even on OW1, there used to be some disconnects here and there. I think most of the time, things have been a lot more stable. I'm not a Competitive Player, but playing Unranked always felt as it should be. At least where I live, South America, sometimes I can get to North American servers (something that would also happen on OW1, mind you). It seems this rarely happens nowadays, perhaps only when there's barely any people queueing for a specific gamemode on my country.

As for gamemodes, there's a couple to choose from. You have your standard game of Overwatch, where you can play Unranked, Competitive, or Versus CPU bots. Competitive also include a Role Queue and Open Queue modes. Role Queue is 5v5, with 2 Healers, 2 Damage Heroes and 1 Tank, while Open Queue lets anyone choose any role during the match, but tanks are limited to only 2 (you can have a match with 4 Healers and 2 Tanks, or 4 Damage heroes and 2 Tanks, etc etc.).

There's also Arcade, which are more of the "party-game" game modes that Overwatch brings. Sometimes you get some that are Event-exclusive, that changes each Hero moveset, or a completely different gamemode altogether (like Prophunt). I haven't mentioned it yet, but in a match, no one can pick the same hero more than once, from your team, but on Arcade, there's a mode for No Limits that lets you pick as many times the same hero. My favorite Arcade gamemode has to be Total Mayhem. It's basically what if Overwatch was Mario Kart, and it's a lot of fun. There's actual strategy behind this frenetic gamemode, and there's a couple Heroes I only play there. Lastly, sometimes there's "Classic" mode, where you can play as how OW1 was years ago. Honestly... the game was really jank before, you can really see the difference if you play that gamemode and what is currently on OW2.

Finally, there's Stadium, which is a pretty recent addition to Overwatch. It makes the MOBA elements on Overwatch even more apparent (no Hero switching, purchasing upgrades at the start of a match, and so on). I have played a few matches and it's a lot of fun, you can really feel the Hero you picked becoming stronger, and there's a lot of fun combinations you can go with. You have stat upgrades, as well more "Major" upgrades that changes your abilities more. Stat upgrades can be purchased at anytime and you can hold 6 at once, but Major upgrades can be purchased every few rounds (with a specific round set, depending if it's Unranked Stadium or Competitive). Though I wish I could disable the Announcer, he is a little too over-energetic.

I think I will now talk about Monetization and Cosmetics. So, as mentioned, this game is truly Free to Play (like 99%). Cosmetics are only for your customization needs, and, does not affect gameplay in any shape or form. With that said, cosmetics can be indeed quite "pushy", and whether you like that or not, it really goes from person to person. I suppose it's the "price" of Free to Play. This game have a lot of Collabs with other IPs. We have had Porsche, My Hero Academia, and even Persona. The skins are very well made, but I do believe some of them might hurt Hero Recognition (Junker Queen's Mob Boss skin is a great example). Most Heroes have very clear animation stances, posture, and particle effects, but still.

Even more surprisingly, is that the game includes Loot Boxes, but not paid ones. You can get Loot Boxes by either playing the game with Weekly Challenges, or get a couple from the Battle Pass. Yes, there is a Battle Pass, and for the Free tier, you can get a couple Loot Boxes, but there's a few more on the Premium tier. Loot Boxes can unlock items that was previously on the shop (!) as well the Battle Pass. I'm not sure if there's items that are unable to be obtained from Loot Boxes, but I have unlocked quite a few things just by playing.

Now, as any Free to Play game, this game is going to make you stick as long as possible playing. You get Daily and Weekly challenges, you get Event challenges, Hero challenges, Lifetime challenges, and so on. Each Hero has their own Progression system that, if you are one of those people who like to try 100% everything what is available for Free, well, goodluck, because it's a very long road ahead. 

I think one critic I have for the game is regards to most of the Support heroes. I feel like there's no good indicator of how much you've healed someone. Yes, there are sound effects, but I like to play while listening to music. Outside Mercy, Zenyatta and Wuyang, there's no real Heal Indicator than Health Bars on top of each one of your allies. Playing as Moira feel like I'm wasting my Heal resources without knowing for sure if an ally is fully healed. Spectator shows healthbars of both allies and enemies on top of the screen, and I feel like this could be added in-game, but only for allies. I also wish there was a small indicator if an ally's Ultimate ability is ready, as opposed in having to open the Scoreboard to check. Basically how it works with Sombra when she hacks enemies, and shows the Ultimate icon, but at all times on allies.

There's also another small critic in regards to performance once you launch the game. For some reason, the game struggles a lot on the first few minutes, so I always recommend going to Practice Range before heading to any match. Once you give it sometime, the game will run properly without any freezes or framedrops. This could be because I play windowed, but I have read online other people having the same problem. When you close the game, it can also take quite a while for the process to end completely, for some reason.

The only "Paid" gameplay thing is the PvE missions, which I have not played. When those missions were added to OW2, during the same day that it came to Steam, a lot of people thought PvE was gone for good, but it wasn't the case. What was removed was the Talent Tree system, where you could change the way your Hero played on PvE missions. Since then, however, it seems that we may never get any other PvE mission due to changes on the structure of the development (Microsoft acquisition) and layoffs. So I would just ignore those PvE missions, and Blizzard doesn't even try to push them anyway. It's on a very small corner on the Shop, and well, if it's fun or not, I dunno, but I heard it's kinda average and the inclusion of the Talent Tree wouldn't bring much.

All in all, I recommend this game. It has improved a lot since it was originally released: 9/10.

.... Now, ultimately this still smells terribly of the corpo greed that ruined what could have been the most beautiful video game of our generation.

1. Tons of characters with little world building or backstory.
2. The overarching premise appears to be missing?
3. Sound design hasn't evolved in almost a decade, including the music.
4. Old maps haven't changed much.

You may have noticed I didn't mention game mechanics or gameplay. Well, that's because it's as good as it was a DECADE ago. Which is great. But Overwatch was NEVER just about being a pure "gameplay/mechanics" driven game. It was about the setting, the presentation, and the characters. All of which feels shallow. Ultimately leaving O2 feeling like looking and touching the dead husk of an ex lover after someone painted fresh makeup on them.

Shocker #1: The games current state as of late 2025 is the best Overwatch has ever been in. Some people will read that and have a borderline stroke, but its the harsh truth many need to face. I've played the game since 2016, and while it may be somewhat hard to remember how it was so long ago, Team 4 have added in Overwatch Classic modes to experience what once was and while its fun taking a trip back to the past, my god has the game changed a lot for the better.

Shocker #2: Jeff Kaplan was great for his time, however the new leadership (Aaron Keller) is way better. Jeff is loved because of his very chill, down to Earth vibe. He's a great guy I'm sure, but lets not forget he was actively trying to turn Overwatch into an MMO... I'm sure that would've been super well received had we ever gotten to that point.

Shocker #3: 5v5 is the better format. I guess this comes down to personal preference, but it seems a lot of people have come around on 5v5, now that we have 6v6 in the game its fun to bounce between the two formats, fun to finally play the new tanks in a 2 tank setting, but 5v5 is still the format that is more consistent.

People are review bombing the game for many reasons, but I'd argue theres really only 2 valid reasons: PvE Cancelation and the Fortnite-ization of this game. As far as the other complaints, here are common misconceptions/reasons why the game is actually good and people are overreacting:
- 5v5 haters need to try it out again after Team 4 really refined it, it really wasn't super polished at the beginning, but after many overhauls and changes it plays so damn well. Plus if you still don't like it 6v6 is literally in the game in both Competitive and Quick Play. 
- Stadium is an actual amazing addition to the game, a new pillar to the core modes of QP and Comp. While I still personally prefer to play Comp, Stadium offers something really special
-Lootboxes are indeed back so... if you really don't want to spend a dime on this game, you can still get shop skins + old battlepass skins
-The game is surprisingly balanced, theres always going to be the people crying over how so-and-so is so OP, but what it usually comes down to is how the player uses that hero. Each hero has the potential to be "OP"

This is still one of the best PvP shooters, and still is the best Hero Shooter by far. I would give this a solid 10/10, but theres still things I miss from OW1 that aren't present in OW2 such as portraits, end of match cards, more consistent way to earn lootboxes, Assault maps in Comp, but most of these are just cosmetic things anyway. Also I hate Fortnite.

It's clowned on to death, and I'm sure lots of people will award me the "CLOWN" because I dared give this a positive review--  but hear me out.

Let me preface this by making it clear that I never played Overwatch 1.  On Steam I have 40 some odd hours, but in reality I've been playing since the launch of OW2 on Battle.NET and have logged nearly 1200 hours total.  

I get the hate at launch, the game was barebones and lacked real purpose.  I get the hate after the scrapped PVE.  After 18 seasons I've seen the game in some really horrible states, but right now?  It's actually so good.  Stadium offers variety, the perk system completely changed the flow of matches.  It's more polished and reactive than Marvel Rivals is, and that's not up for debate.  It's also incredibly well optimized.  

There's still a myriad of problems, but the core game is to a state where they seem trivial.  The monetization is kind of gross but the game is free-to-play, you don't have to engage with it if you don't want to.  In it's current state, I absolutely reccomend it.  It's fast, fun, and addicting.  That could change in a season or two, who knows--  but I think this is the best the game has been since launch.

Dear Overwatch 2,
 
I would like to sincerely apologize for violating the in-game code of conduct. The incident was due to a microphone malfunction on my ThinkPad laptop, which I was unaware was turned on during gameplay. My laptop is quite old and somewhat broken, and with a large family of 11 members at home, it often results in noisy audio during matches. I genuinely did not realize my microphone was active, and I deeply regret any disruption or negative impact caused.

I am a huge fan of this game, having enjoyed it since the disk version. I even purchased the Evasion Bundle and have dedicated my teenage years to playing your game since I first bought it. It truly means a lot to me, and I am very upset that my account has been banned.

I kindly ask for your understanding and a second chance to have my account reinstated. 

I am committed to following the community guidelines moving forward and ensuring such an incident does not happen again.

Thank you very much for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

Three main notes:
- The game has extreme emphasis on paid, "ultimate" skins compared to before. You could argue it's justifiable due to the game being free, but it's not. Most of us were perfectly happy paying the base fee for the game & occasionally buying loot boxes for events. One single battle pass costs as much as many AAA-titles..
- Skins that were released in the past and gained rarity have since been re-released as a cash grab. Gross.
- Broken promises regarding story mode (see other reviews). 

I pre-ordered OW1, played for a while, and am returning now after some years. I immediately noticed the new currencies & change to the shop. I get skins from loot boxes that weren't even showing under the character before. Lots of content seems to be invisible or somehow behind paywalls. I don't understand - they reworked the old system and did it very poorly. But at least I still feel fine not pouring any further money into the game.

Regarding the lack of story content - yeah, it's shameful. Other people explain this better. I was SHOCKED to see they're charging for story DLC. Seriously? You want something like A$100 for a battle pass and some story quests? That's what I originally paid for the deluxe pre-order. Yikes.

I'll keep playing with friends. The gameplay has been greatly improved on since its release and is pretty solid right now IMO. I have fun playing. But I hate Blizzard and their lack of ethics & backbone.

It's worth exactly as much as they're asking which is 0‚Ç¨. The thing is there are so few good games, it isn't worth the time. 

One of these things are usually happening in at least every other match:
1) Team 1 or 2 is substantially stronger, and rolls the other. Neither is fun, or interesting because you already know the result. You're just stuck there either getting bullied or being the bully.
2) A lot of people are potato enough that they won't say hello, emote or anything, and instead grind the front door for half a minute before the match starts.
3) Someone loses their cool, and starts blaming/shaming someone else and therefore someone else gets angry and their teamwork gets derailed. 
4) Match ends and people taunt with some variation of "ggez", and/or someone who performed bad tries to put the blame on another.
5) You performed well, but get no endorsements because people are in a bad mood after defeat which is more often than not caused by how the matches are arranged.

Additionally you can't turn off the chat and play in peace, because then that could cause you to accidentally endorse people who are being assholes in chat. 

I reported probably 50+ people in the time I played. I could've reported more, but I gave a pass to a lot at the beginning. Anyway, I didn't get back a single message that some action was taken. Assholes and cheaters can apparently roam free for weeks without consequences, only then to probably make/use alternative accounts to play meanwhile. And what am I here anyway, unpaid and ignored QA in your storefront masquerading as a game? 

You don't have the money to fix matchmaking?
You don't have the money to fix toxicity?
Fuck off. 

I believe what they do is 100% intentional. First get you addicted, second make you feel bad so you buy some garbage skins from their store to feel good again.

And the store is on whole another level. You can use four different currencies in their store. Since Blizzard is excited for 2026, maybe they've figured out fifth so the milking can become exponentially higher. After going through all the different things and coming to a conclusion I decided to give 0‚Ç¨ to Blizzard. If you get addicted to collecting things without thinking too much, it will not cost you tens but hundreds of ‚Ç¨ in the long term.

Free to play isn't real. Actual cost is your mental health, and possibly your money anyway.

as someone with alot of time back on battlenet. overwatch isnt a good game, and its good parts were thoroughly sanded away by the horrible hand of blizzard. remember "if it isnt fun, its not in the game." that was the original design philosophy for overwatch, piece by piece everything fun was worn away to make something insipidly stale. you WILL use the same team comps. you WILL play the same role every game. you WILL wait in queue. hero diversity was ground away, trying to balance the millions of characters was a fools errand to begin with. just look at tanks, once diverse in playstyle with the throughline of big healthpools. now every tank needs some form of insane damage reduction/negation, needs to be self sufficient, needs to have everything under the sun. and then you have the totally worthless update to "overwatch 2" aka removing features and bringing them back with paywalls. the writing was on the wall the day they implemented hero limits.

Overwatch 2 is a great game, but the performance issues are really holding it back. I play on a 180Hz monitor with max graphics settings, but the game constantly struggles with random fullscreen and windowed fullscreen switches. This results in frequent frame drops, with my FPS often getting stuck at 60, which makes the smooth, high-refresh experience I expect feel choppy.

The most irritating part is when I click on my second monitor for even a split second. The game goes black, and when it comes back, it‚Äôs usually switched back to fullscreen. This messes with my FPS, and I have to quit the game and reopen it to fix the issue. Even then, I can‚Äôt rejoin my match, which is a huge time-waster.

I‚Äôve tried everything, changing the settings to windowed fullscreen via the Nvidia Control Panel, factory resetting my PC (I did this 2 times), and updating drivers, but nothing works. The game still randomly reverts to fullscreen, ruining the experience. And it‚Äôs only Overwatch 2 that‚Äôs having these issues. All my other games run smoothly with no problems.

(I tried Discord Overlay too, turned it off and it's not the problem)

Game is free, so no complaints, the balancing of the game is horrendous.

Started on level 1, vs players that are using characters on level 40+ with hours of XP under their belt undoubtably, I just get murdered within seconds of leaving the spawn point. Some characters feel like your on one-hit-kill, but the other team needs an arsenal engaged upon them. But, it is free, so I'm glad I didn't buy it for $50. Character designs and skins are very fun, and unique. Lootboxes unlock through progression which is good, but to buy coins for the really good lookin' stuff... hope you have a second morgage. Pricing needs looking at, less is more comes to mind. $40+ to buy one skin in the Mystic store... I can buy a full game for that!

But as said, it is free, and despite the occasional drop out, and grinding to get into levels that mean you can last more than a few seconds starting out, it is a fun game. Easy to drop in/out, just very hard to 'main' a character, especially as newer ones aren't included in the League or special modes.

Overwatch 2 is not just the worst game on Earth ‚Äî it's a catastrophic, flaming train wreck of corporate arrogance and creative bankruptcy. It is a disgrace, a scam, and a betrayal rolled into one grotesque cash-hungry mess. Blizzard didn‚Äôt just drop the ball; they took the ball, spit on it, set it on fire, and lobbed it into a landfill filled with the hopes of millions of loyal fans. Every second spent in Overwatch 2 is a slap in the face ‚Äî a reminder that this once-great franchise was gutted, desecrated, and taxidermied for microtransaction profit.

They promised evolution ‚Äî we got degradation. They hyped a rich PvE experience ‚Äî we got a soulless bait-and-switch. They took a vibrant, iconic hero shooter and stripped it of everything that made it special, replacing joy with grind, community with isolation, and purpose with profit. It's not a sequel; it's a parasite latched onto the corpse of Overwatch 1, feeding off the nostalgia of players too heartbroken to leave. The monetization is so shameless it borders on satire ‚Äî $20 skins, paywalled progression, recycled events wrapped in shiny new lies. The game doesn‚Äôt even pretend to care anymore, and neither should you.

Overwatch 2 isn‚Äôt just bad ‚Äî it‚Äôs the end-stage symptom of a once-great developer rotting from the inside out. It is pure, concentrated disappointment, and it deserves to be remembered not as a game, but as a warning sign: this is what happens when you let greed kill art

I hate this damned game.

Update after about 130 hours, I still hate this fucking game.

Well Blizzard, it has been a bumpy road. I purchased OW in 2018 because my friends were all over it and it was crossplay from Xbox to PS4 so I gave it a shot, and then unloaded my magazine. The whole dynamic changed once OW2 was released, some new friends started playing and the old ones left (6v6 should have never been removed). I remained. I remained through the lack of new content and the removal of old (battle ass), I remained through Marvel Rivals, and was beginning to think that the game was dead. I remained and even started to feel good once they added back old content like a political strategy to win players back. But the thing that took me from remaining to living was Stadium. Although it is rough around the edges and is super overstimulating when you try and bring new players into it, I love it. Or should I say loved it. One of the roughest edges is Genji, while most DPS can be out played, Genji's abilities are super frustrating to verse as a lower skill player, in a game mode where you can build around almost anyone, Genji stood out as someone who could always best you with his insane toolbox of weapons. This is due to Genji having so many movement abilities and deflecting 90% of the rosters projectiles. Moira could counter Genji in normal modes but for whatever reason in Stadium I always see Moira either trying to heal the tank or losing to the Genji. TLDR, Genji is a menace, and I (among many others) am suffering a skill issue. I could deal with this however, and still loved the game mode and it is also one hero. I also loved season 18 on launch, with numerous lootboxes and a lot more content to play towards (progression and events), I did not really care for Wuyang but he's alright (Till he got Joker's Skin, peeved about the characters they chose for that). But in the announcement trailer we got 3 new heros to Stadium, WInton (YAY), Pharah (I mean its alright), and Brig (She can be busted but just break her shield). But the last sentence sent chills down my spine "Tracer will be added mid season". I knew this was going to blow hard, but I could not imagine loathing a game mode that I once loved so hard, why would you not add bastion, Venture, Sym, Torb, or any other DPS. Why would you add the other stupidly annoying character and give them more to their already stupid annoying kit. It makes most matches with a Genji and Tracer unplayable, I have rarely experience negative emotions towards a game unless it deserves it (Rainbow or League) but this killed OW2 for me. 

That was a lot of background and complaining. However, complaining and not having a solution leaves you looking like a fool and while I am one for playing OW there can be a fix. My solution, add counter powers, give Sigma the ability to eat beams (not the lame does not work reduction) , give Cass the ability to shoot through shields, etc. Specifically I would like to see lore accurate powers, like Zen or Moira slowing or stunning Genji to make him easier to kill. Anything to bolster characters who have little movement abilities from getting rolled by characters that are as fast as the Flash on crack. This will make the game mode more accessible and the cancer characters less cancerous. PLEASE DO NOT DO THIS AND REMOVE POWERS IN LIEU OF THEM, JUST ADD BLIZZARD, NO DELETING.

TLDR; OW2 got it's act together (finally), Stadium is fun, Genji and Tracer are a cancer to Stadium that needs to be nerfed.  Add counter powers to specific heroes or play styles so it is more easy to master a character and not get rolled.

R.I.P.

Cause of Death: Skill Issue and needs more counters in OW

This is the worst FPS I have ever played. Aiming is optional for 90% of the heroes, and newer heroes just exploit spam even more than previous spam heroes. I am sure the target audience for this game are overstimulated 10 year olds, getting their dopamine hits from the visual and audio clutter and chaos.

What changed from Overwatch 1 to 2? One less tank, MUCH bigger hitboxes from the already crazy large hitboxes in the first game, free to play, aggressive monetization, and a cancelled pve mode they promised.

The game is an unbalanced mess. Low skill ceiling heroes are rewarded more than the few high skill ceiling heroes...an interesting philosophy. You are censored from communicating with anyone in a match until Blizzard arbitrarily deems you worthy enough to communicate with your team (endorsement votes from players). My btag 'Boomer' was also flagged as inappropriate. For a company that prides itself in being inclusive, it is wild to see Blizzard support ageism against older gamers. This is not the Blizzard we once knew. Sad state this game is in.

I used to play this game when it first came out as Overwatch 1. I was incredibly disappointed with the shift from OW1 to OW2 and was very quick to drop the game. That's when Marvel Rivals came out and reignited my love for the hero shooter genre, I was very quick to get very good at Rivals. Now rivals seems extremely boring and repetitive, and the matchmaking and player base of that game has been thrown out the window, there is so much toxicity that it makes old Overwatch Genji Mains look like a joke. Overwatch has recently pulled me back in and i have fallen in love with the game all over again. The new hero Wuyang is phenomenal, very well thought out and very... fluid (like water... please laugh). Overwatch stadium is a lot of fun and very unpredictable, perks are amazing and I am so glad that we have them, and the return of lootboxes is amazing. I've missed playing this game and im so glad to have it back

Idk what other people are talking about how this game is weird or whatever, this game is GAS. Genuinely a fun game with unique characters. Basically, if you don't like Marvel and you don't want to play Marvel Rivals, play this game. I don't like Marvel that much, so Overwatch 2 is definitely the better option. The skins are pretty good, the emotes are fun, etc. Unlike other games like Battlefront II 2017 with the crates and stuff, loot boxes in this game are pretty easy to get and pretty generous with the stuff you can get. I have a collection of skins, and I've only played this game for roughly 40 hours. Even if they're for characters you don't play, that's still a big win in my opinion. Of course, if you want specific skins, they're pretty well priced depending on which ones you want to get. Sure, some skins are like $20.00 USD, but you can also earn credits by playing the game and doing all of the battle pass stuff they give you. The gameplay is fun with minimal bugs that I've found, and it's generally a good experience as a beginner if you play unranked. It's pretty dope.

Clunky, slow combat that does not feel good to play and no my PC is not a potato, I was averaging 150-160 fps.  Ugly, bland art style, several characters that have to be studied to determine if they're male or female. Terrible tutorial that focuses on one character with no real overlap with other play styles.  There is little weapon variety...you've basically got melee or guns and all the characters feel so samey as a result.  The characters are bland, generic and in a few cases seriously ugly,  some of the voice acting is terrible. When I asked questions I was either ignored and given snarky replies, in one told I was "incapable of learning." There are better hero shooters out there, I cannot recommend Overwatch.

There is just one thing I love about this game. They don't tolerate AFK teammates. They punish quickly and harshly to the people that que for a game and then leave. Other multiplayer games should follow their lead and do the same.

[b]An Intentionally Unbalanced Experience[/b]

The matchmaking in this game feels [b]intentionally unbalanced[/b]. While about 20% of the matches are genuinely fun and engaging, the other 80% are frustrating and one-sided.

The system seems designed to give you just enough enjoyable gameplay to keep you from quitting, while the majority of your time is spent serving as [i]entertainment for higher-ranked players[/i]. Unless you enjoy being used as fodder for someone else's highlight reel, [u]I would not recommend installing this game[/u].

Since the update adding stadium to overwatch 2, it has become a mess. I have a 13th gen intel I7 processor and it was running overwatch perfectly fine and I quite liked this game. Came back to it after a couple of months away, tried to play it, tried the new stadium mode, my PC crashed after 2 mins, updated GPU and BIOS drivers to the latest versions, restarted, and tried again, it crashed after 11 minutes.

I've seen a bunch of very intricate "fixes" for this online that have yielded very mixed results, so the takeaway from this is - don't play this game if you have a 13th or 14th gen intel processor, it will freeze and crash repeatedly. Blizzard are doing absolutely nothing to remedy this, so to save my system (which is barely 1 year old BTW) I am deleting overwatch 2 and I recommend others running the same processor do the same until blizzard gets their fingers out of their behind, and actually fix this.

I am now looking for another fun shooter that won't destroy my system by playing it, well done blizzard!

Overwatch 2 will likely never recover from it's botched release, the failed attempt at a campaign, and rather meh first couple of years, but, for the past 10 months the game has been pumping out new, high quality content every new season. The devs have regularly shifted around who is and is not strong at any given time, and the overall game is incredibly balanced (even if metal rank players might disagree, citing moira and junkrat of all characters as busted).

The main complaint people seem to have nowadays is the pricing and distribution of cosmetics, which while valid, honestly is pretty minor, and just shows how far the game has come.

Yeah yeah, the community could be nicer but if you don't want to, you can opt out of seeing or hearing any of their messages. And sure all have a couple of handful of heroes whom we do not like, and in NA and Europe you can get chatbanned for saying gl hf and gg too much (happened to me), but the game, frankly, is in the best state it has ever been. Most of my rounds are exciting and fun, people are actually quite decent on average, and there's a million different ways to approach the 40 or so characters which keeps things fresh even if you like me decide to only play two or three of them.

If you like slightly silly but extremely compettiive hero shooters, this is your game, there is no better alternative. If you liked the game back when everyone played it, you should give it a shot, relearn it, and have some fun with your friends.

Overwatch is better than ever. Community sentiment is ruining the rating, but the game is actually good.

No monetization on gameplay features whatsoever (except for PVE DLC). Quick (but kinda unbalanced) matchmaking. Stadium is good, more chaotic and have engaging push-and-pull. New characters are fun. Old characters are still fun too. Devs do frequent balance changes and meta is changing good amount. Nothing feels really broken in terms of gameplay. 

Give it a shot.
